Pours a dirty brown with minimal head. Aroma is quite fruity - peach, plums, yeast and a touch of straw. Taste is malt, dates, wood and citrus, finishing with a slight sourness and bitterness.
Bottle at Cafe Buitenlust, Oirschot. Decent malty not too sweet abbey dubbel. Smell and taste caramel a lot as well. Good carbo, medium body.

Bottle. Pours hazy deep amber with a medium off white head. The aroma is ripe fruit, yeast, prune, raisins and sweet malt. The flavour is ripe fruity with notes of yeast, prune, raisins, dates and has a long fruity finish. Nice one!

Bottle at the White Horse. It pours hazy red-brown, with a big foamy beige head. The nose is raisin, raspberry, prune, date, fig, yeast and caramel. The taste is wood, caramel, leather, raisin, fig, alcohol warmth, caramel, spice, smoke, salt and bell pepper, with a woody finish. Medium body, foamy carbonation and creamy mouth-feel. Well balanced and enjoyable.

Poured in a Rochefort Trappistes glas... the transparent copper color comes out nicely. The smell is quite strongly sour and sweet, but in a pleasant way. Very rich in carbonation... This I didnt expect from a double.. This one is really distinct from most other doubles i tasted. The more I get used to the taste, the more I begin to like it...

330 ml bottle from Premier Wine and Spirits (Halifax).  Pours a cloudy, deep copper colour with moderate-sized tan head.  Aroma is sour fruit, spice.  Taste is sour cherries, pear, caramel and a spicy finish.  Some drying alcohol warmth in finish.  Nice.

Brown beer with a big and beige head. Aroma is full of dark fruits, red berries, slightly sour, syrup and spicyness. Taste is similar than aroma, dark fruits, spicyness and citrus sourness. Lots of carbonation, slightly biting and quite light when compared to alc. %. Sour, otherwise typical, dark fruity dubbel.
On tap at Blue Monk in Buffalo, NY not too long ago.  Poured a deep, dark brown, and was extremely sweet.  Nothing bad with it, but I dont remember a ton about it otherwise.

330ml bottle. Pours dark mahogany with a fluffy beige head that sticks around nicely. Surprisingly yeasty on the nose with some dark fruit. Kind of boring, really. Light sweetness on the palate with a real funky character and a tangy finish. Not quite within the dubbel style but interesting stuff for sure.

Very fruity and spicy along with small hint of alcohol on the nose. Taste is smooth, dark prune/plum fruitiness,  a touch nutty. There is also a hint if sourness. Pours from tap with basically no head.

Tap at Blue Monk, a very flavorful dubbel, Brown pour, toffee, caramel & sweet malts fill both flavor & aroma. Toffee & Caramel really shine in the flavor. A very sweet dubbel but never less a fine beer
750mL corked bottle.  Poured reddish brown with beige head and lots of carbonation, smells of yeast, caramel and cherry, taste of yeast and hops and sweet malt.

Weak stewed apple nose, slightly musty.. Clear ochre, thick yellow head. Dry apple core flavor. Hot on the back end. Fuzzy palate. Too dry, really wanting a bit of candi. Probably done the way the brewer intended, which isnt way I would have went. To each his own.

A bit pedestrian. Juicy fruity nose of sweet candied cola (a little unusual perhaps for the style) but a very fizzy palate doesnt really deliver any flavours of note. Some peaty cola flavours lurk in the back palate but you have to try hard to find it.
On tap at Get Real NY VBelgian Beer Festival.  Pours light copper with frothy beige head.  tastes of malt, dark fruits, sour cherries, nutty, and yeast.  My favorite Dupont of the day
Draft. Pours amber brown with an off white head. Malty aroma with toasty and sweet malts and light yeasty notes. The flavor is yeasty and sweet, with some grainy and toasty notes. Pretty good.

Bouteille de 33cl. Couleur davantage ambrée foncée que véritablement brune, la mousse forme un joli col qui persiste longtemps. Un style de bière que japprécie tout particulièrement, aux arômes caramélisés, fruités avec un poil de réglisse. Un bel équilibre et une texture crêmeuse en bouche. Très bonne bière, comme les autres moinettes! Trouvée à Vanuxeem - Ploegstaert.
Bottle. Color brown with medium head. Aroma fruits, caramel, sugar. Taste caramel, sour, fruits.

Bottle unintentionally aged about 3 months. Pours dark brown with reddish hues and a thick tan head. The aroma is dark fruits, caramel, vanilla, and alcohol. The flavor is nutty sweetness and spicy. The palate is thin and watery, has lively carbonation, and has a long, mild, bitter finish. I think I may have let it go a little bad.

I probably need to sample more of these Dubbels side by side to rate then better - but then again, I also should have had enough of them already.  Brown, good head.  Lots of dark fruit flavor - especially in the cherry category, but in this case, it was well balanced with the malt.
Bottle. Large light brown head over a hazy red-brown body. Aroma-taste of brown sugar abd sour cherries with a effervescent sour metallic body. Unusual-could have spoilt in transport.

330ml bottle at a cellar bar called Poatersgat. Film-type layer to a cloudy, reddish-brown body. Resin-like hops to the nose. Caramel-fruity taste character mingled with yeasty notes. Dry bitter tail. Likable (Brugge, 03.05.2010).

Bottle from Mane Liquor @ Dupont tasting. Fantastic ! Pours a perfect ruby brown with a two finger white head. Aroma of sweet toasted malts and dark fruits. Caramel is very present. All the caramel comes through in the taste with a load of plums and currants among other dark fruits. Smooth and slightly sweet. Amazing beer and my favourite from Dupont so far

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2011 Sampled from a 750 ml corked green bottle this beer poured a cloudy orange-apricot color with an enormous cream orange-beige head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was sweet bread, orange, must, cream and oregano. The flavor was cherry, sourdough bread, citrus, vanilla, cream, cola and a tart vinegary undertone. The finish was long, tart, fruity and bready. Medium body but overcarbonated. Decent.

Bottle brought home from Belgium. Hazy orange/brownish look with a huge bubbling offwhite head. The aroma is yeasty and vinouse with notes of earth. Sweet yeasty flavor with alchohol and an eartheren finish.

pours clear pale red-brownish with a small off-white head that disappears completely, aroma is big caramel-butterscotch and cherries sweetness upfront - not that subtle. medium hopped - herbal grassiness and citrus. long grassy and dry finish with a citric lemony bite. taste is a load of caramel-butterscotch, tingling alcohool. earthy yeastiness, peppery. average carbonation, medium body. meh.

Pours hazy copper with a large head.
Nose shows doughy and spicy Belgian yeast characters, candi sugar, brown sugar, golden syrup. Also soft spicy/grassy hops.
Similarly sweet flavours, lots of candi sugar. A fair whack of alcohol is also evident. Finishes abruptly with a mild, metallic bitterness. Feels a little disjointed.
Carbonation is too high.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2011 3/04/2011 33cl bottle @ home - BB: 8/2012 (2011-129)
Cloudy reddish brown beer, beige creamy head, unstable and somewhat adhesive. Aroma: caramel, ripe fruits, raisins, sweet berries. MF: ok carbon, medium to full body. Taste: fruity, sour berries, bit of malts, hops. Aftertaste: pretty bitter with sour berries still lingering, hint of mocha.

750 ml. bottle. Corked and caged. A slight gusher when opened. Pours a fluffy, lasting, light beige head, over a slightly hazy, amber  (SRM 12) body.....nose is sweet malts, with toffee.caramel, brown sugar tones, light raisin, slight plum and fig.....taste is sweet malt with fruit tones, including toffee/caramel, brown sugar, raisin finishing slightly sweet, with an herbal bitter finish and accompanying pepper....mouth feel light with carbonation adding a foamy spritz. This is a different Dubbel. The malts, while certainly dominant, do not express the richness of many others, and the phenols (compliments of the yeast) are very present. The mouth feel is light and the alcohol high. BJCP 7/3/13/4/6

33 cl bottle. Dark copper with an off white head. Funky aroma that is peppery and citrusy. Dry and dusty nose as well. The flavor is actually sweet with wheat and alcohol. Some hints of spice. Finishes off averagely malty.
Deep amber-orange with slight  off-white head.  Sweet roasted aroma and taste.

Dark reddish brown with a small off-white head that leaves some pretty nice lacing. Aroma of Belgian yeast, caramel, spices, herbs and dark fruit. The taste is malty and fruity pleasantly sweet without an overabundance of yeast flavor. Fairly full body, slightly dry, sweet finish, and mildly fizzy carbonation. Excellent drinkability from a style whose bold flavors can often walk a thin line between delicious and cloying.

Bottle 330ml @ home
[Trade by Dedollewaitor] Pours hazy brown with a very small head. Aroma has notes of caramel, alcohol and dried fruits. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat to soft.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2011 (Actually reviewed the wrong beer under this name before, hence the re-rate,) 
A wonderfully crafted beer, reminds you of Dupont have secured such a good reputation.  Dark dense brown with a small to medium sized head. Aroma of burnt sugar, raisin and sweet toasted malt. Very rounded, morish and very sweet flavour of caramel, burnt sugar, dark fruit and raisins, esters and a sweet toasted finish. Big wonderfully chewy palate.

330ml botle from a trade with boutip. pours hazed light brown with alasting tan head. yeasty dark fruit and cara malt nose. the flavours is fruity with nice yeasty elements. drier then most dubbles and quite light and playful.
Red-brown color, fruity aroma, small off-white foamy head, fruity coffee taste, high carbonation, abrupt slightly bitter finish. Liked it.

Poured from a 33cl bottle.  Has a fruity and yeasty/spicy aroma.  Notes of bread, pear, and toffee.  It is a clear dark amber color with reddish brown tints(no lighting in bar so hard to really tell).  Has a mostly lasting creamy tan head.  Flavor is a mix of nutty and toffee and fruity.  It has very soft carbonation and med body.  All in all this was a nice change of pace while eating.  Can be paired with numerous foods.  I would def drink this again.

33cl bottle from IPB
Appearance : Clear depp amber with a big foamy white head. Not much lacing.

Aroma : Lots of yeast. Nutty and a bit fruity. Notes of caramel. A bit floral.

Taste :  Yeasty and nutty. Finish rather dry and nutty. Light caramel. A bit floral.

Overall : Not bad. quite drinkable but a bit warm on the finish (especially right after pouring it). Nice yeast. Nothing really exciting.

Tämä dubbeli on ruskea ja samea olut. Päälle muodostuu melko vähän vaahtoa, joka myös katoaa nopeasti. Aromi on rikkaan marjainen, lakritsimainen, jonkin verran alkoholimainen ja hieman hiivainen. Maussa on myös marjaisuutta, lakritsia ja hiivaa. Tässä vaiheessa myös mausteet tulevat esiin. Kuivahko ja hapan olut tämä on. Poreileva hiilihappo tekee tästä täyttävän. Runko ei kuitenkaan ole mahdottoman paksu.

330ml bottle, slight hazy amber hue, with a frothy white-beige head, nice yeasty, fruity ripe apple, spicy nose with a mild sweet earthy grainy toasted, caramel, biscuity malt accent, with some faint herbal floral spicinness in the aroma follows thorugh on a medium-bodied palate with a good yeasty, bubblegum-like, fruity ripe apple, spicy nutmeg, sweet toasted, biscuity, caramel malt character with an earthy flowery hop leafy note, and a kind of tea leaf bitterness and hint of tobacco leafs, leading towards a yeasty, fruity ripe apple, sweet earthy grainy maltiness, hop leafy bitterness finish.

Le liquide est brun rougeâtre.  La mousse saffaisse pour former un anneau.  Au nez, les parfums de malt caramélisé sont traversés par des arômes de bonbon et de fruits légèrement acidulés.  Des effluves dépices timides laissent une place importante à des parfums verts dherbes et de fleurs.   Au goût, le malt doux est légèrement supplanté par des saveurs florales mordantes et par des saveurs légèrement acides.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps moyen avec une effervescence normale et une texture légèrement crémeuse.  En finale, des notes amères et surettes sont à la remorque de notes beaucoup plus douces.

Bouteille de 33cl. (déjà bue sous le nom Moinette II Abbaye de la Moinette) Cette bière est cuivrée-orangée, la mousse est mince, beige pâle et avait presque entièrement disparue à la moité du calice de Westmalle. Premier nez surprenant de pomme verte mais ses arômes se sont dissipés rapidement. Pour le reste du verre on est plutôt dans les épices et le caramel. En bouche la bière est piquante, lalcool est bien présente avec une touche de caramel et dépices.

Dark brown-amber colour, large beige head when poured aggressively. Aroma of roasted malts and alcohol. Taste is an interesting mix of hops and barley, with a very hoppy aftertaste. Shots of whiskey, there aint no champaigne. You have to celebrate - it aint so bad a beer.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2011 On tap @ Rattle N Hum.
Pours clear amber brown with some off-white head. Lots of fruit aromas, banana, caramel, citrus. Medium to fuller bodied, bit of warmth from the alcohol, light sweetness. Very enjoyable.
Awesome aroma of fruit, caramel and spice. Brandy, citrus, banana and caramel malt. Pillowy head. Soft carbonation and creamy texture.
Poured from bottle into small yard, hazy, unattractive brown, moderate head. Whoa, a very sweet aftertaste...very. An unpleasant lingering bitter...hmmmm, not sure about this one.
tap at bridge.  pours a clear copper.   doughy, bready, caramel and rotten fruit notes.  as well as some burnt and toasted notes and marshmellows and old plums.  good not great.

Draft at The Bridge shared by lushawn- thanks, Shawn.  Pours a deep brown color with red and amber highlights and a small off-white head.  Aroma of bananas, dates, floral and herbal notes, earth, and caramel malts.  The flavor stays pretty faithful to the nose, with some additional fruit and sweet bready malts.  Medium-bodied, with a yeasty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.  Pretty nice dubbel.

cloudy light brown with a beige head.  Slight malt, fruity yeast, grassy hops, and a little bit of spice.  Flavor is sweet, fruity yeast with that herbal hop bite in the back.  Carbonation is big, medium body (for the style).  Bitterness becomes more bold as you drink it.  Good stuff!

Really liked this one.  Bottle pours cola brown with medium off-white head.  Aroma malts and spices.  Outstanding flavor with sweet malts, spices, caramel, a bit of dark fruits.  Finish just a bit hoppy, maybe a little more than Id like for this style but not bad at all.  Alcohol well disguised.  Medium palate with carbonation.

Will buy again.
Pours copper/brown with a big off white head. Aroma of Malta, dates, and a touch of hops. Taste is the same with some caramel. Alchohol well hidden.  Decent.

Slightly hazy copper, off-white thinner head.  Caramel malty nose with nice bready/yeasty aroma.  Fuller palate, sharp hop bite.  As it warms the alcohol is more noticeable but not overwhelming by any means.  Caramel and a hint of sweetness provide a nice balance and smooth brew.  Top notch.
750ml.  Pours a slightly cloudy chestnut brown with a dense tan head.  Smells like a bananas foster.  Fairly soft on the palate.  Tastes of toasted caramel, brandy, with a touch of vanilla oakiness.

Poured 33cl bottle into trappist glass.  Pours a nice amber brown color with lively carbonation and a nice thick head that stays for a while.  The aromas are of dates and bananas, with a little grass.  The mouthfeel is perfect for the style.  Not too thick, but you definitely know yo have something here.  Alcohol is well hidden at 8.5abv.  Not too sweet, but very nice.  Tastes of bread, banana and caramel.  Some noticeable hops, bit not overpowering.

330 ml bottle @ home.
Pours a deep red colour with a big off-white head which collapses slowly. Sweet on the nose with cherry, citrus and yeast notes. Fruity taste which is very Dubbel-like. Citrus notes with caramel malts. Light/medium body, oily and watery texture with small yeast particles in the glass. 8,5% abv but its well-hidden. Easy to drink. Dubbel above average, but could be a lot better. Needs improvements on the palate.

Bottle @ home. Houwitser, gusher. Brown reddish pour, large light brown head, lots of small floaties.
Aroma of caramel, red fruit, spices/herbs and hops.
Strong flavour with a subtle sweet note. Caramel, fruits and spices mostly.
Nice beer.
Bottle. Amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is alcohol, dried fruits, sugar. Flavour is sweet, alcohol, sugar, dried fruits, fruit, malt, cellar notes. OK beer.

Bottle. Its a hazy, copper-colored beer topped by an off-white finger-thick head. Cellar, sugar and touches of candy and herbs in the aroma. The flavor is candy-ish sugary, with some hints of cellar, pepper and herbs. Medium to full body, dry and effervescent. Sugary finish with some alcohol warmth and a fine bitterness. A rustic, easy drinkable beer that probably needs some food to stand out. 100331

Bottle:
Slowly disappearing 3 finger off white foam head.
Smell darker spices (pepper) and fruit (.
Clear light brown orange color.
Taste is bit sour. Dark spicy, sweet, dark fruits, yeast, dough, hint of leaves, and liquorice.
Bit grassy (after)taste.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: 330ml bottle. Brown, muddy appearance with a soft tan foam carpet spread across the top. Some yeast in the final pour with a  plum and raisin aroma that leads into a strong throat warming flavour of spiced fruitcake . Thick and creamy in the mouth and even though there is a strong alcohol presence it does not overpower the other flavours. A nice beer.

Bottled sample at the World Beer Festival Richmond, 6/12/10. Pours a very hazy copper-brown color with a medium head. Good head retention and lacing. Toffeeish aroma with earthy and tart notes. The taste is yeasty with notes of toffee, cotton candy, cherries and other fruits, candi sugar and bitter, leafy hops. Medium bodied.

[Bottle] Pours a hazy brown color with about an inch worth of beige head. Aroma of light fruits, sweet malts and some cinnamon/spice. The taste includes nutmeg, light clove, brown sugar and caramel. The finish is a bit more sour and fruity. Not detecting much of an alcohol burn in here. Average mouthfeel and carbonation. Decent, but could have been better.

Had this at the Pittsburgh Great European Beer Festival at the Sharp Edge Beer Emporium 6/2010.  Darker yellow & cloudy. Small vanilla nose. Unique somewhat leather feel to it. Nice amount of CO2 fizz. Rather rude at first then a bitterness sets in for the finish.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: sweet. sweet nose, sweet taste. some little undercurrents of complexity, like a cassia/cinnamon note, and plenty of vinous presence, but mostly just sweet caramel candy. looks good in the glass, but theres plenty out there thats more intriguing and tastier to boot. Id ask "I wonder how itd age?" except that it already gave the impression of some oxidation . . .

33cl bottle. Poured an almost opaque reddish brown with a thin off-white head. Aroma: caramel, mild grapes, yeast & sweet malts, some notes of sour grapes. Taste: caramel, spice, fruits (grapes), sweet malts... all watered down. Thinnish body, medium carbonation. Overall: fair at best... maybe this was just a bad bottle as this was way under par for a beer of this style and, more importantly, from this brewery.

Bottled 33cl. It pours a hazy amber/ nut brown beer with a tall, nicely lasting lacing light beige head. The aroma is yeast accented with banana, caramel, pear, plum, fresh cut grass, almond and faint marzipan showing up. Late bitterness. Strong carbonation. Very drinkable. The alcohol is nicely hidden. Medium to full bodied. Almonds, fresh cut grass, sweat and vanilla sneaking in. Smooth. Surprisingly dry finish which is reminiscent of caramel and aniseed. A pleasant beer with a lot of character.

Small (330ml) bottle, 14C. Reddish brown with a coat of beige head. Aroma of forest-floor yeast, red berries and overripe lemons. Mildly carbonated mouthfeel. Light berries with underlying caramel sweetness; balancing citrus/ herbal bitterness. Moderately dry finish lets sweet/ dried fruit flavours linger. The easy-going lightness of the beer doesnt detract from the complexity at all.

750ml bottle streaked with sediment. Muddy burgundy swimming with bits; shrinking off-white head. Totally get the last raters dunkelweizen comparisons; mulled apple yeastiness on the snout mingling pleasantly with plum and cinder toffee; flavour completely yeast-sodden with notes of spiced apple and polythene; earthiness, walnut hints, liquorice. Quite a generous glug of alcohol on the end. Fierce carbonation settling down as it warms. The yeastiness is as much BC English or even Bavarian as it is Belgian; apple-sodden, earthy, prickling...a little bit overwhelming. Lovely varnished walnut, cranberry and apple strudel aroma as the head dissipates: 8. Think I might actually prefer this out of a smaller bottle not so swamped with yeast, but I suppose its all part of the fun. Ordinary, edging towards...rather good.

Pours a cloudy, light brown with a good, dense, tan head that leaves fairly good lace. Nose and body are that of a dunkelweizen. Nose is estery, full of cinnamon apples, bananas. Taste is cinnamon apples, spices, grainy, carboardy. Slightly tart in the finish. Way off for the style, but regardless is very boring.
750mL bottle, pours a hazy red-brown with a medium head. Aroma and flavour of dry caramel malt, dark fruits and signature Belgian yeast. Very nice, but the blond surpasses this big time
Nose is lovely fruity, sticky and reasonably complex, In the mouth its a bit simple though still enjoyable. Dark fruit, candi sugar and a bit of earthiness with a medium finish.

Pours medium red-brown, aroma is sugary sweet, citrusy, yeasty and caramel.  Taste is sweet, sugary at first with an orange and strong yeast background, also some malts and light herbal hops. The finish has an unusual sourness.  Decent enough.

Bottle 330ml. Delicious dubbel. Aromas of bread, apple, and burnt caramel. Taste is sweet, with some acidity and bitterness, long-lasting tingling finish. Palate is velvety, and full bodied. Brown, with a long-lasting frothy head.
Nice aroma of citrus and fruity esters as well as some hints of yeast, herbs and malt. Flavor is similar, with a sweet lingering malt on the palate and a faint dryness in the finish.

Bottle, sample. Pours murky brown with a small head. Aroma of dry prunes, earthiness, and a licorice-chocolate note. Body is medium in fullness, with mild carbonation.  Flavor is bittersweet, forwarding hay, soil, dried apricot and bakers chocolate. Finish shows mild tartness, more dark, dried pit-fruit. Diacetyl might be lurking around, though subtle. Not my favorite, but certainly unique.

Pours brown/orange with a small off-white head.Aroma is rustic ,spicy ,yeasty with some herbal notes.Tastes rustic ,slightly acidic with herbal and spicy notes.Slightly alcoholic aftertaste.Medium body with some residual sugar ,almost no bitterness.
Nice bruin

330mL bottle.  Pours a murky golden brown, that eventually clarifies, with a thin head.  Aroma of dried fruit (particularly figs,) caramel, alcohol, some roast, spice and a little earthy yeast.  The flavour’s slightly bitter and roasty with an overpowering dry sourness.  Light-medium bodied, average carbonation with a bitter and slightly astringent finish.

Bottled 330ml. -from bierkompass.de; Birthday gift from my girlfriend. 
Darker amber coloured, medium to big sized pale beige head, malty nose with touch of spices. Sweet malty, quite fruity and spicy with notes of caramel and yeast. Slight alcoholic finish. Nothing special here.
750 ml bottle a brown colored beer with a white head aroma caramel malts dry fruit taste caramel dry fruit spices and a sweetness ending

750 mL bottle.  Cider colored pour with a massive off white head.  Aroma of fruits and brown sugar with some faint hops.  Medium bodied taste of apples, caramel, and faint barnyard in the finish with some sour notes.  Even, slightly dry finish.

Bottle at home. Opens with a gusher. Pours a dark amber color with many floaties and a creamy, off-white head. Aroma of brown sugar, dark malts, yeasty bread and red fruits. Somehow a little sharp to the nose and less appealing. Slightly sour, slightly sweet, mostly bitter taste. Dry, spicy and bitter in the end. A little out of balance, but still ok.

Aroma is very enticing- fruit and malt, with a little hop in the nose. flavor is much weaker though, a little alcohol sting and some slight fruit on the tongue. the body is a thick malt, though. Kind of like a watered-down sangria. Like a weaker version of Scaldis noel. Bottle at the Abbey, Miami beach.

2006 Bottle thanks to Tran at Perrys. Pours with a clear brown body with a huge tan head. Spicy and musty aroma. Caramel, bread and peppercorn as well. A bit of grass. Taste is sweet, donuts, caramel, some grass. Light tartness. Very lively bubbles, creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle. I have sat on this one for about a year. Pours a murky brownish orange with slightly fizzy beige head. Aroma is nice, notes of barnyard, yeast, some dark fruit, caramel, a bit of burnt popcorn. Flavor has a bit of sweetness, dark fruit, earthy, notes of toffee, yeasty, nice alcohol spice, very light butter and faint signs of burnt popcorn in the finish. Mouth feel is medium body with lively carbonation. Overall, pretty tasty but nothing I got excited about.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Hazy reddish-brown pour, mainly down to the fact I poured the whole shabang into the glass to get at those viatmins the Belgians often talk about! Good lasting beige head. Aromas of roasted malts, raisins, chocolate, licorice, warm bread,herbs. Very nice. Flavours of marzipan, chocolate, malts, raspberries, some cinammon. Finishes dry with gentle hoppy notes.

Bottle (in NZ). A little underwhelmed by this. The nose did not come through strongly, and there is a lot of carbonation in the mouth. There is a cola-ish taint to the flavour, though there is a good spice and sourness. A little disappointing.

33cl Bottle from Achelse Kluis. Clear red-brown colour, off white to beige head. Aroma of sour red fruits, very red wine-like, malts, some yeast, hint of cinnamon. Flavour is dark and red fruits, vinous, malts, yeast, sour-bitter finish. Medium bodied, prickly mouthfeel. Came across as a mix of a Flemish Brown and an Abbey Dubbel.

Bottle.  Floral malt aroma, hazy amber body with tall fluffy head. Dry flavor with hints of hops, pine and subtle malt flavor... much dryer then other abbey dubbels Ive had, but similar to the Saison
750 ml. bottle.  Dark reddish brown pour with light brown head, very large and fizzy.  Smell is of earthy robust malt which gives way to dark fruit.  Taste is yeasty, fruity, sweet. Nice.
Nose of sweet yeast, light sweet bread.  Color is light brown with a thin white head.  Flavor is again sweet bread with a distant finish of raspberry.  Nice.
7th September 2007. Bottle at the end of a long days drinking at the Chappel Beer Fest. Dark brown beer, moderate carbonation. Tart but not enough to make you wince!

Bottle. The aroma is fruity-sweet and malty. The small white creamy head has a medium duration, the body is dark red. The taste is a little bit bitter-sour, malt, some hints of red wine. The body is medium strong with a normal carbonation and creamy.

Pours a hazy dark red orange color with a nice tan head.  Aroma of sweet roasted malts and dark fruits.  Flavors of roasted malts, caramels and dry dark fruits. Hoppy and nutty.  Low carbonation with a hint of brown sugars and spices.  A sweet, sour and dry finish with some straw finish.  A great beer with a complex aroma and taste.
Olutkellari Helsinki big bottle: dark red clear and in the end with the yeast murky. Super rich tasty. heavenly strong fulfilling

Pours a deep, near-opaque orange/brown/amber with a large beige head. It really does have three different hues in color. I must say that this is one of the most beautiful beers Ive ever seen... Just stunning in appearance. Aroma is complex: Cinnamon, brown sugar, cotton candy, perfumy floral aromas, yeast, cream. Very nice aroma. Flavor has a lot of funky, sweaty horse, earthy farms. Floral nectar, sweet candy sugar counterpoint. Elegant, smooth feel and finish. Weird, different, new experience for me and I like it. I like it a lot actually. Overall, excellent.
Pours a hazy medium orange-brown with a nice head. Aroma is dried fruit and malt. Flavour is sweet and spiced with a subdued malt flavour. Dry, hoppy finish.

Bottle, 33 cl. A reddish to brown beer with a litlle head, disappearing slowly to no head. A hoppy and malty smell, and so it goes with the taste: malty, hoppy with a light bitter finish.Some nutty taste attached also. A beer that comes to the point immediately and doesnt get boring: as it should be!

Green bottle, 75 cl, best before 07/2009, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on October 16 2009; eye: mahogany, opaque, no effervescence, champagne-style beige head that turns into a tiny ring, no lacing; nose: malt, caramel, brown sugar, yeast, light candied fruits, light spices; mouth: malt, caramel, brown sugar, light yeast, light candied fruit, light spices, finale in malt with presence of candied fruits, medium body, not much carbonation, mildly sweet, slightly sticky texture; overall: correct

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille verte, 75 cl, meilleure avant 07/2009, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 16 octobre 2009; il : acajou, opaque, pas deffervescence, mousse beige style champagne qui se transforme en un petit anneau, pas de dentelle; nez : malt, caramel, cassonade, levure, léger fruits confits, léger épices; bouche :malt, caramel, cassonade, légère levure, léger fruits confits, léger épices, finale en malt avec présence de léger fruits confits, corps moyen, peu carbonatée, moyennement sucrée, texture légèrement collante; en résumé : correct

750ml bottle.  Pours a just slightly clear auburn color with a sticky frothy light tan foam 3.5.  Aroma is a mix of cloying rich malt and delicate Dupont yeast, some toffee and light bread.  Flavor is dominated by Dupont yeast, herbal, floral, light esters, some bread and toffee, malt is rich but comes second to the yeast, a bit bread pudding like or English in sweetness.  The finish dries up, a bit nutty, turning bitter with some light raisin.  Medium bodied, very light and airy feeling, dances on the tongue, fizzy carbonation without being the least bit sharp, faint stickiness.   Interesting, but really just makes me want a Saison Dupont.

Bottle. Murky brown colour, thin creamy head. Mocha and yeasty ester on the nose, with some Belgian sournes to it. Medium bodied with spicy notes on the palate. A little dissapointing, may have been an older bottle and Im still getting over a head cold, so probably doesnt do it justice.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 TAP: red/brown pour, semi-cloudy. Thin white head. Peanut and malt on the nose, malty & semi-creamy taste. Grain. Good beer.

Ballingest dubbel ever.

Pours a murky rusty red with a profuse three finger creamy offwhite head. Dissipates quickly. Nose is jumping with character. Nice mixtrue of clove, isoamyl acetate, yeasty esters, bubblegum, and a raisiny malt character. Flavor exhibits the same character, starts off with isoamyl acetate and clove, sweet and fruity, mild spicy aspect and some perceived bitterness. Sweet on the palate with a lovely carbonation and the softest of bitternessess.
Bottle. Pours solid red. Deep white, foamy head.with aroma of fruit and barley. Firm body with an incredibly strong finish, Epic Belgian Strong Ale,

Bottle 33. Dark beer with a nice head, in the trappist style with taste of chololate malt (near Gulden Draak). Quite malty with a small yeast acidity at the end. Hops are very less, well balanced beer, excellent.

Tasyted from that big bottle. Nice brown colour with some light tones and a nice head. Malty and some nice caramel and fruit aromas. Very well balanced not bitter but some nice mouthfeel. Very nice beer.
I found this to be a very pleasant brew and have since searched for another bottle to purchase.

330ml bottle. Pours copper with beige head that quickly diminishes to a ring around the top. Malty, fruity, slightly floral nose that isnt too strong. Medium, fizzy palate that makes it very easy to drink. Flavour has a bit of sweetness, a touch of bitterness, and has notes of citrus, malt, toffee and coriander. This is a very nice dubbel, everything is balanced nicely and the alcohol is well hidden.

Pours adeep mahogany color with a generous head and nice lacing. Dark fruit aromas and flavor consistent with the style. Dark fruit sweetness offset by the slightest hops bitterness. Medium body, strong carbonation, sweetish aftertaste. Not the best dubbel, but a benchmark for the style.

Bottle. Cloudy amber with a small white head. Aroma is lightly earthy and yeasty with some figs and dark fruit. Flavor is sweet and sharp with dark fruit sweetness in the malt throughout. Lightly bittersweet finish with a touch of hop bitterness. Very good.

Bottle. Murky brown with a thin lasting off white head and fine lacing. Nose of dark fruits, burnt brown sugar and alcohol with a hint of toffee. Fruity palate with a thickish body and syrupy mouthfeel. Finishes with a  pleasant fruity bittersweet hop presence. Less sweet than most Abbey Dubbels which is fine by me. No complaints here.

Pour is a murky brown with an average tan head.  Aroma is nice with some brown sugar and sweet dark fruit.  Flavor is much of the same.   A little caramel and dark fruit with a candi sugar after taste.  Not the best dubbel ever but its a worthy attempt.
Lots of malt flavor. Highly carbonated. Sweet. A good overall bruin beer even if it doesnt amaze.

Bottle.  Sweet fruity aroma.  Cloudy dark brown body, large light brown head.  Flavor is sweet and fruity, but less complex than the best dubbels.  A dash of bitterness in the finish.   Pleasant, not outstanding.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy copper golden with a medium frothy white head that diminishes quickly leaving behind decent spotty lacing along the glass. The aroma is a sweet malt with caramel and fruit. Medium mouthfeel and a bit watery on the palate. The taste is a floral hops and yeast with a dry finish. Hides the alcohol well making it easy to drink, a very good abbey dubbel from Dupont.

bottle33cl
pours dark brown, off white head.
Aroma, malty; dark fruits, light roast and caramel.
Taste, roasted malts, brown sugar, end swith a light hoppy palate, light bitterness that follows the sugar with some added currants and light yeast finish.
Tap Publick House.  Aroma of fruits and caramel moving to peppery spice notes.   Taste is very similar but the spices got to be a little too much after awhile.  Was better when it got warmer.

750 ml corked and caged bottle, purchased at Royal Liquors in Kansas City, Missouri. 2.009 stamped on the cork. Pour is hazed dark amber with a 1/2 inch off white head.  Not really any lacing as the head and beer fell.  Aroma of sweet maltiness, followed by the spicy coriander yeast, finally some clove in the back. Perhaps a hint of ginger in the nose as well. Taste is the sweet caramelly malt, moving to honey sweetness, followed quickly by the yeast, which displays the ginger and spice from the nose. Palate is medium, highly carbonated, clean with an earthy finish. This was nice.  This is the fourth Dupont beer that I have had recently purchased at Royal Liquors, and all of them were very skunky upon opening.  Granted, Dupont bottles in green glass, but hey Royal, turn down the heat in the store a bit, and get this stuff away from the windows.

Morgans tasting, 07MAR09. C&C 750, 2006 vintage. This was a big surprise, and one of the stars of the show! Murky brown with a nice beige head. Sweet, mellow caramel and light nuts in the nose, sweet fruitiness. Lightly spiced flavors, sweet caramel and fruit. complex, mellow and delish!
Nice brown beer, dark brown and beige head. Malty taste with fruity undertaste. Some caramel, too. A good drink any time!
Its good but not overwhelming. A fairly muddy appearance and the flavor follows suit. Earthy, muddy, dry finish. Good not great.

Bottle that I picked up at Dranken Geers, March 09, consumed 24-04-09   Pours a murky musty brown and there was a head but it had swiftly departed before I returned back to my bar having put a CD on, so as the Sundays once sang, I cant be sure on the colour of the head though a later pour actually showed it to be light beige. This is actually a quite straightforward beer, its yeast, malty and really quite earthy at times, some caramel also shows and the alcohol is really very well hidden throughout. Its pleasant enough but one of the also rans amongst the Dupont stable in my opinion.  A6 A3 F6 P3 Ov12   3.0

Pours a deep mahogany color with a creamy beige head. Mainly malty aromas with some fruity undertones (cherry and raisins). Hops really come out on the tongue. Nice mouthfeel, but finishes very, very dry.
0.33l bottle from the supermarket. Nice beer but to be honest I prefer Rochefort or Westmalle.

Completely different label but with identical description and alcohol content.  Great hazy-amber color with creamy head.  Traditional banana baby food aroma with some spice.  Less flavor than expected, smooth texture, light carbonation, small bite and little aftertaste.

Bottled from the Carrefour in LIege. This time I took all the Brunes, next time I will take the Triples there. It has misty red/ very dark amber color with rather high head. Caramel in nose. Aroma is is mainly caramel with some yeast (?). Flavour is yeast, and caramel. Alcohol comes through to strong. Could use somewhat less dominating caramel and alcohol.

Dry amber malt aroma with chocolate and caramel. A bit sweet, a bit sour. Very light bodied and dry for a dubbel. The low sweetness is nice. Dark fruits and maybe a hint of tobacco in there too. Nice bitter finish. Dry and refreshing for a dubbel.

Many particles in a caramel brown body, thin tan head. Nose of candied sugar, caramel, and some nice floral hops. Tatsed of sweet caramelized malts, but only lightly, more stress on the hoppy grasses, and nutty finish. Foamy, slightly oily on the palate.

Bottle, 8.5%. Yeasty aroma, some malt. Hazy brown colour. Small tan head. The flavour is yeasty and OK malty. Has a little bread, vinousness. Good roasted aftertaste with a little spicy in the finish.

Draught at TJs:  Sweet aroma of yeast, bubblegum, and spices.  Poured brown with a hint of amber in color with a creamy, dense, rocky, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Very cloudy.  Opaque.  Tastes of yeast, spices, bubblegum, light caramel, slight tobacco, and light resin.  Medium body.  Thin, then dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Dry, yeasty, finish.  Overall, bland and boring.
Bottle, pours amber with a tall frothy head.  Aroma is sweet and yeast with a cinnamon note.  Sweet malt, bitter hops and spice round out the flavors.  Tastes really strong, lots of alcohol.

Bottle (330ml). Poured extremely dark hazy copper with a rocky, lightly tanned head which was average lasting. Aroma was of wholegrain bread with fruitcake, dried apricots, plums, allspice and white pepper. Flavor was of sweet bready malts with a very light bitterness, currents, prunes, caramelized dates, cinnamon and a light metallic finish. Well hidden alcohol content. Medium bodied with light carbonation, a lightly dry mouthfeel, somewhat thick texture and a decent finish. Seemed a little rough at times. I was a little disappointed with this one considering how much I liked the Moinette Blonde.
Dark ruby re with white head.  Aroma of malt and raisin.  Smooth and malty but a bit sweet.  Drinkable.

Has a ruby pour with brown at the sides, there is a bit of haze, gave a small head of off-white bubbles, aroma of herbal earthy flowers, light raisins and dates, some fruit sweetness appears along with the raisins and dates after the ale warms up a bit, flavor of raisins, dates and malt sweetness, some pepper at the finish, mouth feel is a touch more then medium, nice even carbonation, some creaminess on the palate, a real faint touch of alcohol warmth in the background, nothing to distract from the enjoyment of the drink, overall a very nice dubbel, appears to be more hoppy in the nose then on the palate.
Tasting at Brewtopia.  Amber pour, tan head.  Aromas hit with yeast, dried fruit and some hops.  Flavor has raisins, some yeast, nice muted hops and overall this was a pleasure to taste.

750ml bottle, dated 2007.  I picked this up as result of my extreme infatuation with Saison Dupont.  Pours an absolutely beautiful dark copper with a tan head.  Smells like walking into a German Bäckerei where they just opened a large bag of golden raisins.  Body is a bit less spectacular, but has a strong malt and yeast presence.  Well balanced alcohol, body and carbonation with a soft and creamy but not too heavy mouth feel.  Lacks the charisma to be a spectacular dubbel but is very solid and is one I could drink regularly.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32.  Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt.  Pours a hazy medium amber. Aroma is lightly malty,  hoppy, yeasty.  Flavor is moderately sweet, alcoholic, roasty dark.  Not nearly as good as some of the other Abbey Dubbels Ive had recently.
Sweet malt hop aroma with fruit. Murky brown colour with thick creamy foamy head.  Malt fruit flavour with spiritus. Smooth palate.

Poured at the World Beer Festival in Durham 10-4-08, attended with Drbayern and Celticbrew.  Beer pours a nice copper color with minimal aroma.  Not a whole lot of carbonation.  Nice Lacy head.  Sweet malty flavor with a little fruit.  Not a bad beer.

[’06 Bottle, thanks Guerde!] Pours deep amber-red with a good lasting cream head.  Aroma is very yeasty, but also some alcohol, and a little fruitiness (some type of berry). Taste was initially raisin heavy, but then more malt, a little alcohol, some vinous notes and just a touch of honey. Average mouthfeel, smooth and has a long finish. Another very nice beer from brasserie dupont.
Rich chocolate aroma. Flavour sweet, strong, alcohol, fairly malty. Too sweet for me.

(Bottle, 0.75 l, at Kaisla, Helsinki, on 2008-09-19) Brownish orange. Hazy. Medium sized white head. Caramell, malts and fruitiness in nose. Full bodied palate with some carbonation, turns dry. Caramell, liquorice, bitterness, tiny hint of sourness, hops and bit of salty liquorice in taste. Long lasting malty and bitter aftertaste. Quite good.

75cl bottle from Taps Wine and Beer Merchants (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark brown caramel color with one finger white-tan head. Good retention and lacing. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of ripe dark fruit, candy sugar, spice. Flavor is much of the same with notes of bread, yeast, and sweet malt. Some spice and yeast notes as well. Generally medium body with sweet malt finish.

(04 bottle) Pours dark amber with a beige head that slowly fades throughout consumption.  An initial aroma of dried strawberries greets the nose, but is soon replaced by that familiar Dupont yeast which imparts just a subtle hint of funk to this dubbel.  There is also an earthiness and spice to the smell, while an undercurrent of chocolate and dark fruits keeps reminding you that you’re drinking a dubbel.  Further warming reveals more bread and earthy characteristics, with more funk emerging later.  When cold, the flavor is lightly vinous upfront, with a little caramel as well.  These light flavors become more bold and sweet, with a now very strong vinous character emerging.  Slightly tart blueberry and plum also appear and add another dimension of complexity.  The finish of this beer is filled with distinct flavors.  It begins with quick bursts of fruit (strawberry, plum, and berries), then switches to a lingering bready yeast, peppery spice, and then lightly bitter hops dry and lengthen the finish for many minutes after drinking.  The mouthfeel is medium, very smooth, and the alcohol is unnoticeable.  This is an excellent dubbel, and age has treated it exceptionally well, which yielded great complexity and ultimate drinkability.

At $10.15 for a 750 ml bottle this is not inexpensive. Poured a cloudy amber with very large off-white head and great lacing. Nose of caramel malts and some ripe fruit.  Smooth mouthfeel. Flavor tends toward the ripe fruit. Long biter and sweet (how do the Belgian’s do that) finish.
Hazy pale brown colour. Toasty malt flavour, a little dry at the end. Nice tasting beer but nothing spectacular.
pours golden amber with large head.  Aroma of sweet malts and yeast, straw and caramel.  Flavor of fruit and spice.  I really enjoyed this beer.  Very smooth and drinkable.

750 ml bottle. A cloudy medium amber beer with a huge, persistent, creamy beige head. The aroma is quite malty and yeasty, with notes of caramel, dark fruits and figs. The flavour has the same fruity notes and some more spiciness. Medium sweetness and a touch of acidity. Good mouthfeel, pleasant and smooth, medium body, lively carbonation, quite long finish with almost medium bitterness. A well balnced Dubbel, great appearence and mouthfeel, and becomes better as it warms.
75cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, hazy, good head, nice balanced brew

750 ml bottle-A burnt orange hazy body with a nice tight tan head and an aroma of belgian yeast, caramel, and brown sugar. Taste of the same with a nice candy, malt, and a dry finish. A very nice drinkable Dubbel.
Sweetish smooth drinking dubbel.  Deep brown with some white head.  Malty yeasty aroma.  Medium, almost creamy mouthfeel.  Mild yeasty spiciness.  Drying aftertaste.

Bottle shared by Jeremy at Ginger Man.  Pours a dark brown ale with light tan head.  Aroma is spicy belgian yeast, some dark belgian fruit.  Some hop character and lightly sweet in the finish.  Decent beer.

A hazy brown ale with a thick creamy light moka head. A spicy caramel aroma, light orange peels and bubblegum, with light alcohol. In mouth, a burned caramel malt, coriander and orange peels, with good warming alcohol in finale. Medium bodied. Bieropholie import. Tasted early April 2007.

This 2007 corked and caged bottled brew poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that left behind a very hazy dark orange brown colored body with no visible carbonation.  The aroma was thin with brown malty notes.  The mouth feel was crisp and tingly from start to finish.  The flavor was of brown malts mild hops with a mild vinous note that came out after it warmed up.

Pours a cloudy amber orange with a healthy beige head that reduces to film after settling. Aroma is sweet mango, banana, toffee and slightly floral. Flavor is fruity, floral, herbal and spicy hoppy. Finish is floral and sweet. Medium to full body, sticky texture.

Pours caramel brown with off white head. Aromas of Belgian yeast and bananas. Sweet flavors of dark fruits, bread dough, caramel and yeast. Medium body with lively carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. A very good dubbel

Bought this in Quincy, MA in an 11 oz bottle that had the same description as on this site (but very different label). Sweet, honey-ish scent. Thin, white head atop a cloudy, deep, honey-coloured body. Decent lacing. Taste is a mix of sweet fruit and hop bitterness with a lasting bitterness at the end.

Bottle, Belgian Belly, Manchester. Poured a muddy dark ruby with an off white creamy head.  Floral, yeasty aroma with a dash of citrus and hop thrown in da mix. Flavour is sweetish and floral again, with a healthy slab of dark fruit, malt and spice. Full bodied and chunky, this has definite chracter and is very drinkable.

Tawny amber brown, translucent. The initially large off-white head recedes rapidly leaving no lace. Aroma is yeasty and figgy. Sweet caramel, fruity yeast (berry, cherry), medium bitterness, quite dry.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Pours a lovely cloudy brown with a light beige head with decent retention. Sweet caramel and ripe plum aroma. Tastes wonderful! Light sweet breadiness, caramel & a sturdy & well-blended spiciness; detectable are cloves & light banana. This would indeed work very well with barbecue. Nice, coating body with excellent carbonation. Very, very sessionable. Very very tasty!

Medium head,rather strong though,red/brown pour with good carbonation.Aroma cloves,raisins,caramel,malt,banana.Flavour figs,raisins,malt coriander,clove,banana notes,this is nice stuff,very smooth,took a big mouthfull,very good flavour.Finish,mellow ,mild sweetness,tops.
Little caramel, some fruit and spice in there. Will have to try again as it was to wash down a particularly hardcore curry. Not my favourite brune but I really should try this again.
Tap at Toronado. Pours with a dark brown color. Nice aroma of dark fruit and caramel. Flavroful with Belgian yeast, caramel and more fruit. Medium bodied with hardly noticeable alcohol notes.

Brownish copper color color.  Aroma of nail polish and bacon. Orange, lemon like fruitiness and sweetness on the palate.  this is an elegant and sweet ale that will please many.  Nice complexity and cheap fair price.  Awesome BEER!!!

Slightly murky reddy brown body with a short off-white head. Malty aroma, a little grainy and a little caramel. Taste is of light roast bitterness along with a little pepper, touch thin in body, easily drinkable though not that memorable.

Botella. Hazy deep red-brown colour. Deep malty aroma with a mild bitterness and some frutiness. Good mouthfeel. The flavour has a good deep maltiness with toasted caramel, a good hoppy bitterness and some dark fruits. Tasty brrew indeed. Hvala Jesper!

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2008 A red/brown colored beer, with a nice, not quite white head. the aroma is fruity and some malt and yeast in the back. The tast is light bitter, and most of all fruity, like cherry, with a toch of citrus and some beries. A very appetizing beer on warm days.
Molto buona ha un carattere un po particolare tipicamente dupontiano che però nel sapore un po troppo aggressivo/erboso non mantiene del tutto le promesse dello splendido bouquet.

Corked & caged bottle with 2007 on the cork. Medium sized very fizzy ivory head that mostly diminished, very little lacing, hazy, very little carbonation, and a copper-orange hue. Nose was flowery, hoppy, fruity, sweet, and malt. Ditto for the flavor with some spice. Tingly mouthfeel with a bit of a warming sensation and medium in body. Very quaffable, nicely done, and worthy of a try.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2009 This beer brought the funk.  Funky, rubber nose.  Intriguing; almost overpowering.  Malt and peat, too.  I swear I tasted french fries somewhere in the taste; a weird one.  May have been a bit off.  Still good.  Re-rate: crazy fruity yeast and none of the crappy metallic notes sometimes seen in dubbels... quite nice.

Bottle at Den Dryver, Brugge. Warm brown, nice tan cap. Lovely elusive aroma: oranges, honey, caramel. The heathery, softly peaty quality of Bowmore. Toasted caramel flavor with a hint of Christmas pudding. Dry effervescent finish.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 33cl. bottle at home: Pours a lightly hazy dark tarnished copper. Creamy tan head with staying power. Soft sugar nose with caramel, some fresh red plum and low malts. Some mixed herbs lie underneath everything els. Every once in a while a touch of toast pops up. Alcohol is lightly present on the nose. flavors of dark caramel intermingled with bitter herbs. A touch of cardboard and nuts floating on top of alcohol. Herbs and alcohol make a somewhat harsh combination. A light roast pops up as the beer warms up. Long sweet and bitter "green" finish with some malt wanting to fight its way forward. A bit "unrefined" and even harsh overall.
Pours an amber color with a nice large frothy head.  Aroma and taste is green apple, some grape, and some sugar.  Quite enjoyable.....seemed to have more familiar with a Saison-variant, though.
Pours a deep amber color with thick frothy white head.  Aroma and taste is of green grabe and apple with belgian canied sugar

(3/2/08) Draught (I think) sample at Zythos Bier Festival 2008 in Sint Niklaas. Aroma of malt and carmal, a bit of yeast and a bit of alcohol and some spiciness. Swet malty flavor with some caramel and some fruits. Finishes dry and a bit alcoholic. Medium-bodied. Decent but not very impressive.

Bottle (o.75l): Hazy, amber coloured, quite stable brownish head; fruity (sweet plums)  and vinous (diluted port) nose with a light acidity; medium to full bodied, solid sweet-tart flavour; bitter-sweet-fruity (raisins) finish. Well crafted....

Forgot to rate this one from the other night. Somewhat dissapointing. Color is about what you would expect. Nose is a bit spicy and malty, as is the taste but there are notes of metal and fruit also. The taste is really mild and at 8.5% dissappears very quickly. Not bad.

(75cl bottle) Cloudy, murky amber colour with a massive and moderately persistent beige foamy head. Slightly sweet toast-malty, slightly vinous and fruity (apples, plums, ume) notes. Light-bitter flavour, medium to full bodied with an almost smooth carbonation. Delicate toast-malty and vinous fruity taste; dryish and lasting toasty and fruity finish. Quaffable (12.03.08).

Bottle from Dilly Deli.  Poured clear dark brown color with a large frothy light brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Good caramel, vanilla and yeasty aroma. Medium body with smooth texture. Full well balanced sweet fruity flavor with a medium complex finish of long duration.  Good brew.

Bottle. Light unclear medium amber color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, caramel, brown sugar, candis, moderate to heavy yeasty, sulphur. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (190208)

As Belgians go, this wasnt bad.  Light brown with a fizzy chanpagne head.  Lots of yeast and fruit, spices in the nose.  Sparkly in the mouth.  Sweet caramel and fruitiness in the flavor but nothing very appealing.  Decent for a Belgian.
Pours a coppery brown color with a thin white head.  Aroma is fruity, spicy, nutty and malty.  Very crisp with hints of hazelnut, grape, chocolate maltiness, hops and spice.  Very clean crisp finish.
Reddish color and pours nicely.  Nice body with a fruity aroma.  Taste some roasted hops and has a herbal tint to it. No alcohol taste.  Very nice.  WIll drink again.

750 cL bottle from Marcus. Thanks very much!!!! Aroma is blended grape, earth, spice, and arguably hop. Beautiful reddish coppery color with a beige/tan head that fluffed up and didnt completely leave. Thin to medium body with creamy carbonation. A bit bitter with some roasted malts. Heat is noticeable in the sinus. How about floral/herb hop, roasted malt, touch of chocolate and some mild spice or herb/veg. The aroma is very refreshing. The finish is mostly dry and that chocolate note seems more noticeable. A really satisfying ale.

Yep.  Cloudy cider appearance with red notes when light-touched.  Lasting, tiny-bubbled off-white head.  Musty aroma of grape and rum cake and, as many have said, Marzipan.  The dry, dusty mouthfeel is a nice canvas for flavors of grape essence, mildew, Chocolate, banana, and random spices.  Ending has solid bitterness to intertwine with the malty sweetness.  I dig.

Tasted 25/12/2007. 750ml bottle from Regional Wines and Spirits.  Pours a brilliant oxblood red. Airy white head slowly disappears. Marzipan, rum and raisin. Some sugar. Dry, kind of sappy and cleansing in the mouth - almost laquer-like in the texture.  Plenty of toasty malt character.  A little spice and alcohol in the warm finish. Mild bitterness. Palate doesnt quite deliver what the nose promises.  Lovely warming drop, all the same.
Reddish brown colored pour with decent sized head.  Grassy, hoppy aroma with a bitter malty finish.

Bottle. Ruddy brown colour with a big tan head that left plenty of lacing. Aroma of spice, the barnyard and earthy hops. The flavour was sweet and fruity to start before a pleasing dry, hoppy finish. Good.

Bottle purchased at Sam the Beer Man in Binghamton, NY. Pours opaque apricot, thick, dense off white head. Aroma is dried fruit, honey wheat pretzel, malt, metal (copper). Flavor is the same; tangy metallic.
33 cl. bottle. Clear red/brown with a small white head. Lightly bitter and medium sweetness. Aroma of malt, spices and marzipan. Alcohol in the finish.

75 cL bottle. Pours golden orange, clear, and with a diminished white head. Aroma is slight spiced and malty with a whiff of alcohol. Flavour is sweet and spiced with a subdued malt flavour. Has a nice spice note along the way and into the finish. Solid, but the weakest from Moinette.

Bottle. [thank you, yespr, shared @ Plan B]
Pours a pretty and very clear, but rather pale, amber (not brown at all). Head is big, rather foamy and off white. Aroma is lightly sweet with a little dried fruits  certainly not like a dubbel. Flavour is lightly malty sweet, rather powerfully vinious and warming. The dried fruits appear again at the final aftertaste. Rather nice, but there are so many better alternatives.

Bottle.  Muddy orange with a fizzy, big top.  Aroma is sweet and grapey.  It drinks with a bit of a spicey edge, a bit of banana mush to it, too.  Warms your gullet.  Classic to the style.  (#3199, 11/10/2007)

Pours a hazy medium orange-brown with a nice head. Aroma has lots of floral hops and funky yeast, with some citrus in there as well. Flavor is a standard Belgian brown ale profile... brown malts, yeast, hints of mushrooms, with some very mild spices as well. This bottle seemed a bit stale, not what I remember this beer tasting like, though when I drank it before I wasnt as experienced a drinker as I am now. A good beer for the price, but not that much better than Kasteel. Im going to have to revisit it, though.
*My bottle has a different label than the one pictured.

Pours brown into the glass with a nice off white head.  Aroma is very yeasty with some sweetness to it.  Flavor is very malty with those same earthy tones that you get used to from the saison.  This beer, much like the saison, seems to expand in your mouth.  Very delicious

Rated blind from "Better Know a Style: Abbey Dubbel" tasting. Pours a clear orange with a beige head.  Aroma of caramels, grapefruits, and toffee.  Flavors constitute citrus, caramels, toasted, red fruits, hops, and faded hints of pine.  Balanced well and pretty tasty.

Rated blind from "Better Know a Style: Abbey Dubbel" tasting.  Clear light brown color with small creamy off-white head.  Aroma is very light, apple, brown sugar.  Flavor is very yeasty, alc and red fruit are strong with prune, dough and some hop residue rounding it out.  Medium to full body, somewhat creamy.  Very nice and hoppiest of the beers weve had.

Bottle. Average off-white thick and bubbly head that mostly lasted. Good display of lacework. Hazy light brown like colored. Notes of caramel, hint of toasted malt, some yeast, hint of underlying citrus and acidic. Fruity, earth and somewhat light spicy feel over the palate. Medium bodied with an average carbonation. Light to moderated sweet flavor with light acidic and hint of bitter notes. Sweet fruity with a twist of acidic finish that are somewhat lingering. Not youre typical Abbey Dubbel, but quit nice.
Bottled. Hazy rusty reddish/brown colour with mediumsized head. Aroma is zest, barnyard, some seedyness and caramel malts. Flavour shows some signs of alcohol, yeast, herbs, fruits and caramel malts.

Pours orange-gold with a half inch of white head. Lacing is fizzy and sticky. Smooth nose of orange slices, small barnyard funk, grass, and creamy wheat. Tastes are analogous with the aroma with a subtle addition of pepper and alcohol. High carbonation and medium/full body. Not very memorable, as it tastes like a hundred other Belgian ales, but still good for the price.

Poured a hazy almost rust color with a decent head. Aroma was yeasty with some mild toffee.Taste mild yeast ,hints of toffee and spices. Slightly dry finish. I thought this was rather watery and bland for the style. It looks good but doesnt deliver. A "so so" beer. Glad this was a gift.
Pours brown with a tiny head. Aroma has malt, toffee and a warming alcohol. Sweet flavor with overripe fruits and toffee. Very decent brune.

rated blind from "Better Know a Style: Abbey Dubbel" tasting. pours orangish-red with off white head. nose is bready, yeasty, peachy. flavor of peach, apple, plum, very fruity. mouth feel a tad fizzy, long finish. nice stuff.
Yeasty aroma with thick tan head. Flavor is sweet with hints of raisins, caramel, toffee, and sugar. liquorice flavor on the finish. candy in a bottle

(Bottle) Pours yeast hazy reddish brown with a creamy off white head. Yeasty and malty aroma with tones of fruits, red berries, prunes, raisins, sugar, caramel, butter, fudge and some light spicy notes of vanilla. Hints of floral hops. Creamy and sweet nose with some earthy tones. Fruity and caramelly flavour with tones of red berries. Undertones of earth and more subtle hints of liquorice and chocolate are also notable. Soft and velvety mouthfeel with a sticky twist. Medium sharp carbonation. Fiery finish. Medium to full bodied.
Poured a dark brown with a large frothy head. Has hints of typical belgian yeast, dark candied sugar, nut, spices. Finished spicey and boozy.

Pours amber, with a great foamy head. Aroma is very floral, hint of toasty, spicy. Lots of orange and coriander, maybe some nutmeg. Flavor is excellent, very much delivering on every bit of the aroma. A most delicious, very fabulous example of the style.
Pours redish brown with a beige head. Aroma is toffee and floral. Taste is malty, sweet. Very hoppy end. Full body and strong

0.33 l bottle. Mahagony color. Strong raisiny aroma with chocolade, dark sugar, rose and soft alcohol note. Chocolade, raisings and figs in the flavor along with yeast and warming alcohols. Fairly light bodied.

(2006 bottle) A slightly sweet aroma with hints of dark fruits.  Pours a reddish amber color, with a small off-white head.  Interesting flavor, notes of wood, fruit, yeast, and a touch of alcohol.  Long oak/bitter finish, fairly light in mouthfeel.  Overall, a good beer, but not something Ill go out of my way to find.
A nice example of the dubbel style: warming,  enjoyable, spicy and even a bit nutty or earthy.

In the bottle from Dundee Dell. Cloudy mahogany brown. Medium thick head is by no means explosive as many Belgians. I get that very belgian medicinal surge from this. Thick and fairly incapable of hiding its heat. tastes a bit like chewing a piece of sycamore. Nice level of sweetness- maltiness is a touch like horhound candy. I like the cranraisin flavors as well.

750 ml bottle
$6.99 at Steves Wine and More in Madison.  This was recommended and sounded interesting.  At the price my expectations were not that great which is good - this beer is solid is all aspects but mostly average as a whole.  There is very little to set it apart from any other standard dubbel.
Aroma / Appearance - A two finger generously foamy head cascaded down the sides of the glass before the bronze colored main liquid began to appear.  Lively carbonation kept things busy at all times.  Apples, oak and a rich chocolate somehow combined to form an almost underwhelming nose.  It sounds much better than it actually was even with the hay scent providing a base.
Flavor / Palate - Cherries, peach and chocolate mousse open the session.  A base of roasted malts is a solid foundation on which everything is built.  A hint of wheat and oakiness offset the mild hoppiness present in later sips.  On the whole it hits all the right notes but somehow I still found it a bit disappointing.
