Murky golden-copper body with a medium beige head.  The Dupont yeast doesnt feel as wild in this one as in many Dupont beers.  The dominant flavour is berries dipped in thick creamy caramel.  Yeasty notes of bananas and bubble gum.  Distant cherries.  A little residual sugar.  Generously hopped, more so than in most of their beers.  Body is full and silky with a typical lively Belgian carbonation.  Something about the silky body gives the impression that the beer vanishes away very quickly from the mouth.  Far from my favourite Dupont this is nonetheless a wonderful beer.  The guys at Dupont cant seem to do anything wrong.  Unlike married men who never seem to be able to do anything right, or so they are told.
Clear copper colour, firm white head. Aroma of dark fruits. Some alcohol noticable. Taste is dark fruits and some alcohol tones. Balanced and easy drinkable.
colore rosso intenso profumi fruttati lampone frutta rossa un buon corpo mediamente amara
On tap at 12de Oostendse Bierjutterij. Cloudy copper with a creamy beige head. Fruity and yeasty aroma with some caramel. A hint of chocolate in the caramel flavours. Yeasty spiciness. Very likeable.
Still fairly dry.  Aroma has hints of red fruits but the flavor is all woody nuttiness.  Nothing to write home about.
Bottle, 33 cl. Reddisch brown color, white head. Aroma yeasts, dark malts, hops. Medium body. Taste = good in balance malts with the sweetness and a touh of fruits. Dry finish.

Had on draught at Brouwers in Seattle.  Aroma is sweet malt forward, with high fruit esters and strong caramel tones.  Beer is a hazy dark auburn, with a persistant off-white head.  Flavor is also sweet malt forward, with lots of fruit ester tones, peppery notes and low bittering.  Mouthfeel has a warm alcohol/grain bite with medium carb feel and a light creamy smoothness.  Overall, I thought it was extremely smooth, with reasonable complexity and some malt notes that seemed almost english in flavor.

On tap at Monks Cafe in Philadelphia.  Pours a cloudy brown with an average off white head.  Aroma of dark fruits, brown sugar, nuts, some chocolate and sweet caramel.  Flavors of dark fruits, Belgian yeast, spices and some chocolate and sweet caramel.
Bottle. Quite murky fith bits of sediment floating about. Has a frothy, medium thick khaki colored head. Very bready, almost salty aftertaste. Full bodied, very high carbonation.

75 cl bottle at Delirium café, Göteborg, Sweden. Hazy amber, with medium creamy beige head. Sticky malt aroma with raisins and some chocolate. Smooth mouthfeel. Alcoholic, sweet, with moderate bitterness that is not enough to balance this beer.

750ml - 2006 - Appealing aroma of chocolate and Dupont yeast mixing with some ripe dark fruits.  Pours hazy brownish red with a small head and great lacing.  Flavor is fruity first but is quickly followed by lots of chocolate malt and that signature yeast spiciness.  Palate is tart and creamy.  Another very tasty brew from Dupont, one of my favorite breweries in the world.
In bottle at De Zolder. Light brown with small head. Skunky sweet/sour nose. Much more bitter than the normal brown/dubbel. Not sweetened. A nice departure from the crowd of sweetened browns.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Fruity nose.  Poured opaque dark amber out of the 750ml bottle.  Had a flavor of sweet caramel and fruit.  Full creamy body.  Heavy on the palate.
Pours a light amber brown color with a light tan head.  Aroma is malty, spicy, and a hint of tart fruit.  Flavor is spicy, light on the malt, with a tart finish.

Bottle shared at a blind tasting.  Thicker head than some of the other dubbels sampled.  Some light spices, fruits, and a dry finish.  Personally this finished last out of the 9 dubbels I tasted, however, since this was more of a non offensive brew, it finished higher among the less experienced raters in our crowd.

Bottle.
Hazy brown coloured with an off white head.
Aroma of fruits, dried fruits and spices.
Flavour of fruits, dried fruits, spices and hops.

Shared with KAggie97 at the end of the DFH tasting at Flying Saucer in Houston. Dirty brown pour with small  head. Candied fruit flavor, but not overly so. Light crisp body that makes it easy to drink.

Sampled at a blind abbey dubbel tasting hosted by tennisjoel on 4-14-07, along with eight other beers. This was the sixth beer that we tasted. It finished in third place in my rankings, but it was sixth place in the group rankings. Originally poured from a 750 mL bottle. The overwhelming winner of the night was t Smisje Dubbel, with Corsendonk Pater finishing a strong if distant second.

Yeasty, wheaty, relatively strong aroma. Orange/curacao scent. Smells like orange-flavored chocolate candy. Pours a largely opaque, bright orange/amber with some bubbling and a large amount of beige head. Orange flavor. Sugar sweetness, but its not too sugary. Bitter chocolate aftertaste (surprisingly bitter, given the sweetness in the taste). Light to medium in body. Lively and refreshing in the palate. Feels like a lighter beer than it is. I liked Moinette Brune quite a bit.

Pours a murky dark brown with a rocky off white head.  Lots of fruits in the aroma, caramel apples, yeasts as well.  Sweet body is at first malty, then a bit friuity,  and finishes with a hint of bitterness.  Not cloying in its sweetness, not overly complex, but definitely not ordinary.  Worth picking up.

Bottle, Dark copper with flakes in suspension. Creamy and fluffy tan head with good retention. Aroma is dominated by red apples and some dusty notes. Sweet and fruity flavor with hints of diacetyl. Slightly watery with short aftertaste. The alcohol is not smelled, tasted or felt. The combination of fresh fruit and staleness seems a bit odd to me.
Fruity nose. Dark fruit taste with bread behind it that swirls into sour apples. Finishes with spice tinge.

Bottle. Sugary sweet aroma, with some really nice fruit and herb notes. Peaches, plums, raisins, honey, and some mild sourness. Thick-looking brownish amber with minor head. Flavor is unique, sweet and balanced, with some sourness. Palate is smooth and a little dry.
Faint, yeasty aroma with lots of spices and a hint of smoke? Or is it burnt caramel? Color: Brune? Well, more like dark-orange, really... Nice head. Very dry taste, but delecious.
A classically well-made brown ale. Dark malts and mildly bitter, green hops alternate from nose to tongue to throat. Avoids sweetness almost altogether. Dry finish.

Such a nice friendly lovely beer! Pours with a nice big foamy light tan head with lots of lace. Cloudy dark amber/ red oak color. Very very malty sweetish beer with just enough bitterness - mostly from yeast and a bit hoppy, tad from dark malt to yield an excellent flavor and body. Tempted to gulp it. Yummy! Sharring a 750 ml bottle here with an old friend Frank Van Voorhis at the Bodega Brew Pub, downtown La Crosse, Wisconsin.

Poured a murky brown, with a reasonable head (cant fault it on the haze as I shouldve taken more care when pouring) it has an intruiging nose of malt, coffee, spice and fruit. Good body with a complex palate and a fine finish. Brought back from Amsterdam by Ronnie.
Bottle (at Duvel cafe Sthlm). Ruby colour. Wonderful aroma of red fruits (and Swedish "hallonsnören"). Lots of hops. Quite nice.
Bottle: Poured a light brown amber with thin white head. The aroma was hoppy fruit. The taste was a rich caramel malt with a nice spicy finish.

Great Brune!  This is a tasty Brune.  Although not perfect and not as good as the Abbaye des Rocs, this is still a delicious Brune with rich and complex flavors.  A yeasty and rich taste of fruits and spices.

Dark brown with a red hue and a nice head. The aroma has notes of yeast, fruit, caramel and the mouth feel is oily. The flavour has notes of yeast, spice, fruit, candy sugar and alcohol. The finish has citrus notes. OK, but not outstanding.
33cL bottle.  Cloudy caramel color with uniform off-white head.  Average bruin flavor with a slightly burnt aftertaste that lingers a little.

This beer pours an opaque reddish brown with a tan head and malty aroma.  Very evenly balanced.  The flavors were malt and dried fruits with a light roasted flavor.  Very drinkable.  Good creamy palate and carbonation.  Drank a full 750 ml bottle in front of the fireplace during a power outage, perfect.

pours a murky brown with a huge creamy almost tan head.  volcano shaped head.  one of the best looking beers ive ever seen.  aroma of caramel, citrus, yeast, and hops.  flavor is bready and bitterly hopped with a hint of brown sugar, and caramel.

Bottle. High white creamy and lasting head. Hazy orange body. Complex fruity aroma dominated by plums and raisins. Dry malt flavor with raisin and caramel notes. Not especially bitter, enough though to hide the alcohol taste.
cloudy yellow hue,.  Yeasty with bitter aftertaste.  very good.

Dark amber/brown color, with almost purplish highlights.  Thin tan head with some large soapy bubbles.  Aroma of fresh plums, grapes, and cherries, along with dried dates, raisins, caramel, molasses, and a light spiciness.  Flavors were rich and malty, loaded with dark fruit flavors, caramel, a hint of cocoa, as well as a hint of warming alcohol.  Very minimal carbonation, which I quite liked in this beer, as it allowed the flavors to pass over the tongue uninterrupted.  The alcohol was present in the finish, but along with the hops, served to bring out the flavors more fully.  Very good stuff.

(750ml bottle) Bieropholie Private Imports. Pours a large, frothy, tan head with a deep brown body. Nose of wild yeast, wrinkled apples, wheat germ, vanilla and brown sugar. I really get a flavour of unripened green bananas - even the chalky pasty finish. Deep dark malts play in a field of long grasses, corn syrup line feeds a dividing path. Very nice.
Bottle -750. Carmel, nutty with some plum in the middle. Deep brown, not much head. Good, Belgian-fizzy, but not too fizzy. Still a little thinner than Id like.

This beer would likely be better if the bottle were better cared for.  There was a STRONG skunk and metalic flavor/aroma that really spoiled this one for me.  Other than that there was a nice banana and light chocolate aroma with a caramel and hop aroma with a firm bitterness that did not linger.  I really need to find a better cared for beer as this had great potential but was ruined by the liquor store that carried it.

Hazy amber with a large head. Sweet aroma of malt, vanilla and honey with some yeast and Seville oranges. After that the taste is a bit disappointing: sourness predominates with some rather alcoholic sweetness in the background. Dry ending. Im sorry to say I havent really got on with the Moinette collection.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a medium creamy head. Aroma and taste of malts, fruits and spices with a alcoholic finish.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2009 Thin head of fine bubbles.  Very good carbonation keeps a thin foam on the surface.  Excellent aroma with cookie dough, apricots, black cherry, sweet malts, brown sugar and some caramel.  Damn this aroma is good.  Just hope that the flavor stands up as well.  Color is a hazy dark orange.  Malty, yeasty with a little fruit and some spices.  Simple yet very good.  Quite refreshing.  Hides its alcohol pretty well.  Finish is a little pasty and malty with a little lingering yeast and spice.  A damn good dubbel!  Got to find me this one locally.  Boy I really like these Dupont beers.

On tap @ Anam Cara.  Pours a dark brown with some red glow in the light.  Aroma is wheat, yeast, and a bit of malty fruits.  Taste is semi-sweet fruit and yeast.  Finishes a bit sharper.  Good stuff.  Brasserie Dupont friggin rocks.

750ml bottle dated 01/03/2004 via trade with Duane!  Thanks!! Shared after thanksgiving dinner - Pours dirty amber with a nice frothy belgian tan head. Aromas of caramel, candi sugar raisin, yeast, and some other fruity notes.  Flavor is caramel, raisin, candi sugars, and yeast.  Medium body and pretty dry on the finish.  Smooth soft mouthfeel.  Nice brew..

Draft at the Flying Saucer.  Poured a dirty looking brown, with a half inch bubbly off-white head.  Very cloudy.  Aroma was kind of tough to detect on behalf of the smokey bar.  However, the taste was nice and strong.  Started with some dried fruit (plums, prunes) and some ginger tastes.  Also, some light bread and grain tastes.  Fairly sweet, almost candylike at times.  Fruit flavors lend to an overlying tartness.  Finishes with a pear taste, and then dries out immensely due to that classic Dupont yeast.  Med/light mouthfeel, but creamy, and the carbonation is not QUTIE as carbonated as the Vielle Provision.  Good stuff, fruitier and less malty than other abbeys Ive had.

The aroma has cola, yeast, vinegar, and fruit. The appearance is cloudy purple brown with a nice foamy head. The flavor is sweet and bitter without being too strong or too weak. The palate is average for the style. Overall its pretty much what I have come to expect from Belgian ales.
a tad thin, in the palate its got great fruit flavors with caramel malts and strong alcohol content. yeast is quite apparent
33 cl bottle. Cloudy brown, full rounded sweet and sour flavour, vinous lingering finish. Fine beer for sipping, warming afterglow.
Hazy brow-red. Begie head. I can´t find much of aroma. Maybe some burnt sugar and dark fruits. Has a malty and dry flavor. Sweet, fruity, yeasty. Little bitter in the end.

Bottle. Darkish brown with a white creamy head. The aroma has fruity hops, bread, yeasty spice. Smooth sweet butteriness. Bread maltiness is apparent - generally leaning towards that actually. Watery at times and reasonably dry.

Brown-orange color served in a goblet with a good 1/2 inch of head on it.  Smell was floral and appealing.  Taste was fruity with significant sourness, but still enjoyable.  The sourness tasted like a sour ale I once had that was aged in pinot noir barrels.  I believe this is the first Belgian brune Ive had, although it struck me as similar to a number of dubbels Id previously tried, and that comparison is pretty favoriable.  I would recommend and would try again, but its not the best Belgian-style beer in my recent memory.

[bottle] Pours a dark, murky brown color. Substantial tan head. Aroma is fruity, with some solid yeast in there as well. Sort of sweet flavors, with some subtle spiciness and bitterness towards the end.  Not overly complex, but still a well-rounded, tasty brew.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry, Blankboy, and MDS, Blankboys bottle.  Deep hazy brown, small white head.  Yeasty aroma - lots of yeast, little spice.  Yeast and malt feature in taste, pretty average stuff.  Fruity, malty.  Nice simple beer that just didnt do a lot for me at this tasting.  Very drinkable though, no alcohol at all.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, mds & tupalev -- my bottle. Pours a murky orange-ruby with a huge lasting off-white head. Aroma is malty with yeast and spices. Sweet flavour of caramel malt, sugar candy, yeast, spices and alcohol with a dry bitter finish. Not crazy about the aftertaste. Medium bodied. Not great but pretty good.

2006 750. Beer is murky, medium-dark hued strawberry-brown color with a large, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting head. The aroma is malty with moderate-to-heavy lush notes of toasted grain, caramel and cookie; Hoppy with light notes of lemon zest, pine, straw and herb; Yeasty with light notes of dank basement, barnyard, trace of rye bread dough; Trace of apple, light note of alcohol. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic and moderately bitter with a dryish average-length, lightly acidic, lightly bittersweet finish. The body is medium, the texture is watery-velvety and the carbonation is lively. Strong and enjoyable, but not lyrical.

Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy, mds and tupalev, blankboys bottle.  Poured an attractive shade of orange-ruby with a huge beige fluffy head.  Dry spicy/yeasty aroma, light sweet brown sugar malt.  Sweet and fruity malt flavour, lots of spice, alcohol and yeast - quite a bitter finish, but still sweet and malty - very tasty.  Only average body, slightly astringent mouthfeel, bitter and moderately alcoholic finish - I really enjoyed this one.

Bottle. hazy red brown, big creamy golden head. Fairly spicy nose. 
Very peppery/spice base flavor, herbal edges, berries,  clayish. Estery citruspeel aftertaste. Vineously big
Pours out a nice cloudy brown color with a huge tan head.  Aroma is hoppy, malty, and sweet.  Flavor is malty and finished with a sweet touch.  Very nice brew.

Bottle from Charlotte Oktoberfest 2006.  Pours out a brown color with a big billowing brown head.  Smell is fruits, yeast, malts, and somewhat smokey.  Taste is similar, rich and fufilling.  Not a bad Brune beer really.  If I see this on the shelves I will probably buy a bottle just to get a more complete sample of it.  Pretty nice.

Bottled.  A dark mahogony colour with  ashort=lived off white head.  The aroma is very rich and Christmassy.  Raisins and candied peel.  Sugars, and malts.  A lovely nose.  The taste is long and malty.  Again candy sugars and brown fruits and a good dose of alcohol.  A very well brewed dubbel but one shopuld suspect this from Dupont.

A large, fluffy beige head dissipated rather quickly above a hazy, tea-tinted bronze body. Tannic, sour, wooden aroma with alcohol showing sharp & medicinal late. Light metallics float on a fluffy palate. Acidic, fruity flavor pairs light and dark fruits while alcohol adds bitterness and a dry finish. Disappointingly unimpressive.

Bottle. 

Great beautiful dubbel with notes of "brown" fruits. In balance and a finish with a hoppy bitterness.

Bottle from Super Saver, Somerville, NJ.  Pours turbid orangish ruby with 3-finger off-white head in my Stoudts tulip glass.  The aroma is heavy floral and spicy notes, some earthy yeast, some hops and citrus.  Smells like a mix between a dubbel and saison.  The flavor is dry, very floral and spicy, with a herbal hoppy mid-palate and some fruit.  Fairly complex, but gets very spicy and dry as it warms.
bottle. light amber color. large head. sweet aroma. lots of malts and dark fruits. kind of thin.

Abbey Dubbel no sir not quite. Poured dark orange with a copper tint to it with a white head. Aroma is sour with some apple and flowers notes. Herbal aroma. Flavor is dry with belgian yeast, and some lighter sweet fruits. Finish is dry and herbal. Not very much going on here. Dissapointing.

Dark amber-brown coloured, very light carbonation and a small diminishing off-white head. Roasted coffee-caramel aroma, light yeasty and fruity touches. Full, malty body, light alcoholic touch. Finish is sweet-yeasty with a clear alcoholic touch that lasts rather long and gets stronger near the end. Despite the strong ending not the best beer, no balance.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a medium sized head. Sweet - roasted malts with weak notes of caramel and raisins. Very slight hint of citrus. A bit too thin though.

Bottle: Poured a medium brown color ale with a medium off-white foamy head with average retention. Aroma of cookie dough malt is present though too subtle for my own taste. Cookie dough malt can also be detected during the tasting but again it is a bit too discreet. Sweetness is also noticeable but yeast characteristic are also too subtle. Body is thinner then expected and alcohol is well hidden. Overall, while still being a good abbey dubbel I was expecting much more from one of my favourite Belgian brewer.

2005 bottle. Pours a very active brown into a tulip.  Significant, frothy tan micro head with excellent retention.  Light dried fruit notes.  Dry with upfront caramel and a lasting sour/bitter alcohol finish.

High pressured bottled, the cork ejected by its self after the basket was removed - Amber appearance thick small-bubbled white head  malts ,dried fruit ,sour cherries, yeast, grass, hay nose- taste yeast, slightly malty , pears , cereal ,  and some brown sugar   - bubbly thicker  body  aftertaste frothy, sour and malty

Dark copper with an off white head. Funky aroma that is peppery and citrusy. Dry and dusty nose as well. The flavor is actually sweet with wheat and alcohol. Some hints of spice. Finishes off averagely malty.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours bronze with an off-white ead. Aroma of  spices, citrus, and fruit. Flavor is fruit, citrus, sweet, with a slight bitter finish. Great beer.

Had Vielle Provision and thought it was great, so I picked this up. Its delicious. It has a fair bit of hoppiness for a dubbel style, but I think it balances quite nicely. There is also a bit of fruitiness which is very nice. I would prefer if the color was a little darker. Also, the mouthfeel is a little thin for me.
Robe rousse voilée surmontée dune mousse beige épaisse persistante. Arômes de fruits, de levure et dépices. Saveurs de fruits, de cerises marasquin, de levure et de malt acide.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2006 Deep amber and hazy body with an off-white and mostly lasting, medium head.  The nose is citrus, spicey and with malt and yeast too. Malty and fruity flavour of pears and lemon. Small notes of acidity.  Medium bodied. Long fruity and slightly bitter finish.

A couple of years old  Best before 05.2007  Beautiful amber body, white head, The nose is not sweet, but is has a lot of sweet aromas to it: spicy honey, sweet fresh apple, it actually smells of sweat as well; The body is super smooth, soft textured, soft carbonation; Quite long finish where roasted malt notes are the most apparent, together with lots of sweet fresh apple. GREAT BEER!!!

I have to say this was rather dull for a dubbel -- nicely refreshing on a summers day though -- perhaps not something I was expecting out of a dubbel at 8.5.  I found the aftertaste to be a bit chalky -- prefer their saisons so far.

Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours murk orange\bronze with a huge off-white ead. Aroma of belgian style spices, citrus, yeast, fruit, alcohol. Flavor is fruit, citrus, yeast, sweet, carbonated, slight banana?, mild hoppy bitterness, spicey, and smooth. Good body, good brew.

750ml bottle - Hazy orange copper with a huge dense light tan head. Looks fantastic. The big fruity and spicy aroma is very evident from the second the cork pops off. The flavor is quite nice, an interesting mix of a dubbel and a saison, lots of nice funk and fruit throughout. Dry prockly mouthfeel. Good stuff.

Sour, funky, fruity distinctly Belgian nose.  Beautiful rich amber to copper beer with a huge foamy off white head that settles down, slowly vanishes, and leaves a film and wonderful lacing.  Big full mouth, almost cloying.  Complex taste of sweet toffee and sweet spice, yeast, dried fruit, and sourness ... maybe green apple sour, not citrus sour.  Long, slightly bitter finish.  Warm but alcohol not too obvious in the flavor.

750.  Pours a murky brown with a huge head that dies down to a nice pillow, perfect appearance.  Wild, sour fruit nose, with a faint touch of funk, vinegar, and herbal woodsy notes.  Flavor is yeasty, a tinge of sourness, apricots and dried cherries, green raisins, and other fruits.  Herbal finish that is somewhat bitter, drying things out.  Full bodied.  I would drop this in the saison family, but who cares, this is a fantastic beer.  Dupont Brasserie has never failed me, I dont think anything has scored outside of the 4s that Ive tried.

Sweet caramel and bready aromas from a light brown beer with a massive head and lots of lacing.  Theres also quite a bit of astringency on the nose and the tongue.  Grapefruit, orange and some bitterness from the hops.  Extremely dry finish.

2004. Very dark ruby. Large, fizzy, hissing, tan head settles quickly to a thin layer. Dusty basement funk, earthy and peppery yeast, dark fruits, candi sugar, anise, subtle vinegar, wood mulch, rich and roasty caramel malt backbone. Dry, yeasty finish. Full, just to the sparkling side of balanced palate. Two years has treated this brew very nicely. Complex.

750ml poured at The Vine restaurant in OB, San Diego. Beautiful beer in the glass, deep copper color, very clear. Thin, off-white head, but some stubborn lacing,  Flavor is all almonds and cheese, believe it or not. Really great fizziness on the tongue. The flavor notes are so unique -- I dont recall ever using cheese to describe a beer -- almonds maybe, but not cheese. Im thinking artisan, some farmer locked in a barn with sweat on the walls, as he patiently waits for his soft cream cheese to mature. Not camambert, not brie, this is of the same ilk but brings something else. Mysterious and elusive, and totally great.

Bottle 50F Trappist Glass.  Lots of esters, yeast aromas are very dominate, a bit of fruit, quite sour, very delicious.  Deep yellow color, with a wonderfully foamy head, with nice lacing.  Nice flavor, difficult to find exact flavors, well rounded finishes lightly sweet.  Very light hops, but adark malty taste not present by looking at it.  The appeareance and smell decieve, this brew is larger than it lets on.  Mildly acidic, rustic tastes of grainy breads.  Very nice and very delicious.  Very good mouthfeel, tight carbonation, but finishes easily.  I really think this is a very nice beer, a great example of a delicious Abbey Dubbel.
Copper/ruby body.  Creamy off-white head.  Nose is grape soda, grape skins, nice & malty.  Flavor is rich grapey malt, caramel, yeast, clove-like spices.  Quite nice.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2007 (bottle): Pours a reddish brown, lighter brown edges. Tan head, good sized and lasting. Good lacing. Flowery sweet aroma. Fruity, dark like raisin, and light like pineapple. Flowery taste, some malts. Dark fruit. Soft mouthfeel. Some alcohol. Just okay.
dark r/b color, big not lasting head, full one, caramel, chocolate, some fruits.....roasty end, good bruin

75cl bottle cork dated 2004.  Chestnutt brown color...off-white head leaving thick lace.  Aroma first off is musty...shows some fruitiness like grapes and figs...seems decidedly different than the paler Duponts.  Drinks dry with a nicely done finish that seems to me a bit more bitter than sweet...mouthfeel is full...a lingering earthiness rounds out the first impressions.  Spicey still...just when Im thinking that peppery Dupont yeast is hiding in this beer, I stumble upon it...and its always been there.  I see that here it is listed as a dubbel...a farmhouse one at that...it does have plenty of the marks of a dubbel...but also of a biere de garde, I think.  The finish is hoppier than Im used to in a dubbel...more herbal and earthy...but dry enough...there is also a bit of rising dough character in the flavor...and I could probably go on and on about this tremendous treat...the beefier malt backbone plays great with the Dupont yeast...this is a very nice change of pace from the rest of their stellar line-up...and every bit its equal.

750cl. dark brown with white head. Very soft and filling when enters the mouth. Dark fruits- nut and caramel. Medium crabonation. The finish is rather sweet. The bottle I had was from 2003, maybe that was why? (Dupont rocks)
A solid offering.  Thick, frothy head and a medium amber body. Definitely hoppy.  The alcohol is well masked at 8.5%.

Pours amber with a mostly receding light tan head. Aroma of apples, raisins, toffee, and caramel. Taste is sweet and phenolic with notes of apples, plums, toffee, and alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy bodied and slightly sticky with lush carbonation. Fruity, spicy, yeasty, with lingering caramel. Sounds delicious, but was this was missing just a little something.

Bottle. Chestnut beer with thick lasting beige head. Earthy brune with some toffe, but mostly an earthy/muddy quality. Not as nice as the blonde. Some odd flavour running through it like burnt coffee.

Pours a hazy blush amber with a large loose head. Crisp fruity aroma with some sulfur, ammonia, plum  and caramel. I get some hints of Shiner Bock in the aroma, strangely enough. Sweet and sour plum flavor with some cinnamon, caramel and cola. Smooth, clean finish. Rich body. I had a bottle the other day that wasnt as good as this one.

Dark amber colored, hazy appearance. Medium sized beige head. Chocolate, toffee, spices, mild licorice and alcohol in aroma. Medium to full bodied. Crispy palate with some carbonation. Toffee and chocolate in flavor, alcohol comes up too much in aftertaste. Aftertaste is also mildly dry with some licorice.

A truly first-rate offering--very impressive to non Belgian Beer fans in its lovely 750 bottle.

Its a quirky brune--a bit hoppier than usual, but providing ample quantities of caramelized malt behind it.  Not overpowering, but very pleasing with a bit of spice to it as well.

(Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm) Colour is dark amber to brown. Nose is earthy, fruity and spicy. Taste is earthy, spicy with a dsitinct bitterness and a strongish sweetness in the finish, never overshadowed by the hops though. The earthy and hoppy house style of Dupont is very prominent, thank you.
Strong malt, spice, clove, fruit flavor. Robust smell of coffee and port wine. A really good brew with lots of character.

This brown ale poured with a massive brown head (good idea to use a tulip glass) that lasted for a long time. There is a very pleasant malty aroma. There is a full brown flavor that is less sweet and more hoppy than most of the other Abbey Dubbel examples I have tasted. This is a very nice brown ale.

This is a rich, delicious, Belgian brown with that signature Dupont hop character, but with some nice dark malty and nutty character as well. This beer weighs in at a warming 8.5% abv, and makes for a wonderful winter brew, or the perfect beer to match with rich, hearty fare. 
Moinette Brune pours to a beautiful, deep chestnut to brown color with a big, thick, dense, pillowy white head and a lively carbonation. The nose on this beer is very fragrant with pungent grassy/herbal hop aromas paired with aromas of sweet and nutty malt, and hints of ripe fruit. The palate is firm on the tongue with lots of good sweet malty and nutty flavors paired with undertones of fruity acidity. Moinette Brune finishes with more nutty and fruity flavors, then ends a touch sweet malty, and slightly hoppy. 

Wow. Yet another world class beer from this amazing little Belgian brewery. Moinette Brune is as the label suggests, a perfect beer have as an aperitif, or to match with a hearty meal. Indeed pair this one with marinated, grilled, and barbecued meats, or a classic Belgian dish such as carbonade flamande, or mussels steamed in this very beer. It would also make a delicious desert beer, and would go great with NY style cheese cake.

Pours a murky dark brown under a lasting yellowish cover.  Aroma of sour black cherries accentuated by white grapes a touch of marzipan and alcohol.  Maybe hints of banana too.  Unfortunately, the flavour is seriously one-sided due to overuse of sugar adjunct.  Dark malt is apparent in front of moderate, woody bitterness and a sour, dry alcohol.  Really not that complex or dynamic in flavour.  Light to medium body with a little residual sweetness and alcohol warming.

Creamy and adherent foam, discreet persistence. Enough dark brown reddish color; much hazy and impenetrable one, very elegant. Rich and complex, a lot wrapping and long-lasting scent. Powerful alcohol and candy notes. Wrapping and dense taste with a modest bitter. Decided and prickly Moinette Brune emanates persistent alcoholic notes with sweet malty, honey and sugary aromas. A lot balanced with a long and pleasant final.
Pours a dark amber brown color, small white head. Aroma is funky, heavy on the nose, spice and barnyard. Flavor is sweet, lots of ripe fruit, bitters, and a smooth finish. Thanks Logan!

Bottle looks different but has the same name.  I dont know the vintage.  But, it pours to a thin white headed amber/brown body.  The aroma has that basement smell.  This is more like a biere de garde.  Light tartness.  Perhaps its over the hill?  The flavor is tart with that biere de garde flavor.  The palate is sweet and lightly dry.  Typical basement-ish palate.

(on bottle)Amazing colour;  hazy abricot-dark-copperish with a small, steady pale beige head. Aroma is just slightly tart, but with kandis, apples and cinamon being dominant, great sniff. So soft it could be velvet. Expends in the taste, strats of with strawberries, gooseberries, canesugar and pepper, finishing of with raisins, port and a dry earthy feel. Super duper.

Bottle, ABSdrinks. Dark amber colour, unclear body with large particles. Small brownish stable head, no lacing. Hoppy aroma, dark fruits, citrus. Initially bitter hoppy citrus taste, more malts and fruits in the finish.

Of course this is delicious, being Dupont and all.  Red/burgundy color, with a large, beautiful head.  Rustic, herbal hop aroma, with hints of cork, farmhouse, banana, milk chocolate and various red fruits.  Distinct Dupont character, unbelievably rich, full flavored from the front palate to the finish.  Juicy, vinous fruit flavors initially, followed by a mild tartness, which leads into a spicy, peppery herbal hop finish

Soft yellow body with a decent head that lingers a slight bit.  Smell of coriander, sweet grassy malts, and a musky smell like a barn on a wet fall morning.  Palate is very smooth, aside from the slight cold, which makes me wonder if this bottle is a bit old.  I bought it at Main Street Gourmet in Oxford, Ohio, which does not get the best turnaround.  So the aroma was a bit more musty, but the flavor is more sweet.  Almost sugary but more fruity.  Like a non bitter lemon mixed with tangerines.  Ok, so I just noticed the cork said 2004.  In that case this palate is not that impressive.
Light brown color.  There is an aroma of apples, with some Belgian style funk.  Flavor of weird, but good yeast and medium bodied malt.  Made me think of Orval. Fairly heavy palate. Very good.

Bottle: Cloudy amber, light head, light lacing. Nose of plums, bright licorice and brown rice. A bit of alcohol and special B malt. The flavor has a little yeasty tang but its very balanced. The finish is nice and creamy. Good beer.

Pours an extremely cloudy brown body with a large head. Aroma is yeast, candy sugar, malt, spicy, alcohol, and some fruit. Flavor is the same. As it warmed it didnt get better or worse. Definitely enjoyable.

Bottle. Nearly opaque reddish brown, with 1.5cm off-white head. Great aroma; sweet, malty, fruity, spices, chocolate and fresh yeast. Bitter then sweet taste, malty, spicey and some warming alcohol.  Nice smooth and full mouthfeel. Good dubbel.
hazy red w/ yellowish head.  fruity and yeasty aroma.  full bodied, sweet and malty but well balanced by hops.

750 ml corked and caged bottle pours a bright cloudy reddish orange with a decent off white head of large bubbles that leaves some lacing in my glass. Bready, fruity chocolate and spice aromas, fruity pear, apple, caramel. chocolate and spicy flavors. Medium bodied with a mildly carbonated, smooth mouthfeel, finishes a bit sweet.

Bottled, sampled at Delirium Café, Göteborg. 
Clear dark amber. Aroma is dominated by butter/diacetyl and sweet malt. Flavour is ashy malty with a malty, dry bitterness. This is a beer with both sweetness and bitterness.

A Mes rate: 
Damn this scored a LOT higher than I thought it would. Its the smell that makes this one. Like cola cubes and rhubarb and custard and other sweets you used to have as a kid. A little pineapple in there too maybe. Slight bit of funk and yeast. Nuts are present too. Sweet, creamy full bodied great finish. Looks a pretty fine too. Very much on the amber side of a dubbel with a good creamy thick head and slight lace. ACE stuff, I was most surprised.
Delicious if not totally mesmerizing.  More hop bitterness than Ive seen in most Belgian browns.  More sourness and youd have a perfect brown.  Still very good.

Bottle. Copper-brown color with a big light beige head. Spicey aroma with malt backing and a hint of citrus. Earthy malt flavors - spicey, some citrus, a bit of a farmhouse aftertaste. Pepper, licorice, corriander.
Bottle from beers of Europe. Good abbey dubbel from Dupont, with their funky yeast aroma on a malty buttery caramelly beer. Works quite well.

Aroma:cokked vegetable,grass....
Appearance:Hazy orange brown-good tan head...
Flavor:Bitterness,dark fruit and vegetable....

33 cl bottle, bbe May 2007. Until I lay may hands on a 75 cl again, let this count... Rather turbid light brown brew with a beautiful orange hue. Beige fluffy head, large bubbles, dissipates quickly. Alcohol is present in the nose, along with caramel and flower honey and citrus; nicely entangled. The flavour is somewhat malty, with notes of overbaked bread, built upon by citrusy fruitiness, gentle spice and very gentle bitterness. A breeze of alcohol again. Solid palate which nevertheless misses enchantment.

Medium brown with huge beige head. Lots of malty/yeasty banana in aroma with some stale/musty hop presence.  Flavor again malty banana with lots of spice, some alcohol burn in the finish. Lots of woodsy character. Well done.

Keg @ Akkurat, Stockholm 30 June, 2005.Very unfiltered... Orange to brown in colour. Weak head. Sugary malty aroma with a green sweet pepper touch. Tropical fruits also present in taste. Leaves a sweet residue on your lips. Salmiak aftertaste. Quite thin body for this strength. Lively taste diversificaton. Difficult to rate; good or bad, I dont know...

From a 750 ml bottle. Poured a dark amber and orange with a light tan head. The aroma had caramel, cherries and oak. There was also a buttery, almost lactic note under the whole aroma. The taste had sweet peaches and some spice of cinnamon. There was alsoa  little bit of dry oak. Plenty of carbonation kept the mouthfeel playful. The aroma was just a little strange to me.

Bottled 330ml (BB 10/2007)
Dark hazy nut brown color, firm off-white head, floating yeast particles. Fruity, yeasty nose, a bit similar to Saison Dupont. Medium-bodied. Soft mouthfeel with a warming alcoholic background. Mildly spicey. Citrusy bitter finish. Very well-balanced.

750ml Corked 2004 Cork shoots out like a rocket. Almost clear and brownish amber in color with an initially large head that diminishes to a thin layer.  Aroma is malty and fruity with notes of plums, vanilla and cinnamon. Yeast yields some nice doughy bread noytes. Alcohol is faint and well hidden. Earthy aromas as well remind me of russett potatoes. Go figure. Body is medium and slightly oily yet crisply carbonated. Flavor is on the sweet side, with yeast and light hop bitterness adding complexity to a fruity lightly sour malt profile. Overall one of the better Dubbels Ive had.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Bottle from Styles.  Pours a very hazy brown color with snowglobe-like floaties.  A think and retentive tan head leaves fairly foamy lacing.  Musky old-hop aroma and spices in aroma remind me more of a saison in aroma than a dubbel.  Malty sweet flavors of caramel and nuts blend nicely with more hop bitterness than I would expect from a dubbel.  Medium bodied and smooth.  Residual yeastiness.  Nice.

An all around decent Belgium brown.  Nice aroma different spices.  Head is decent with nice beige color.  Quite a bit of carbonation.  Shifts flavor through the drink, a little spicy at first and then a nice sweet aftertaste.  Okay to come back to.

Bottle:  Courtesy of Styles.  Very fruity aroma with some yeast and light alcohol.  Pours a reddish-brown with no transparency.  Off-white head.  Fruity up front with a raisin and toffee.  Finish is somewhat hoppy and lightly spicey.  Fruit and caramel linger into the aftertaste moreso than the hoppy finish.

(Bottle 75 cl) Comes as "Moinette II Vieille Biére Forte". The dark one from Moinette isnt really that dark. More greyish brown, river-water look with a small off-white head. This is a beer with sound, a lovely bubbly sound appears from my glass. Stronger and less sweet than a typical Dubbel, with notes of caramel and dried fruits. 171097

On tap at Bistro 2005 Belgian Fest. Medium amber color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is fruity and sweet with a touch of caramel. A medium bodied abbey dubble. Malts are fruity and sweet, Touches of caramel and a little bready. Nice balance. Smooth taste. Has a very nice crisp dry finish. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Corked bottle.  Pours a nice brown/amber with a thick head that settles a tad too quickly for my liking.  No lace residue to speak of around the glass.  Aroma is slight ginger and coriander.  Palate is slippery and slightly thick, and it eases down the throat nicely.  Taste is a dull grapefruit mixed with some winter spices.  Nice, subtle hops bite on the back of the throat in the finish.  Alcohol provides a slight sting, but does not overpower and become the focus of the beer.  Definitely worth a try.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Nice light brown colored beer with good beige creamy foam. Nice roasted aromas well countred with fruity accents and sweet touches. Some fine pine bitter hints in the nose. Taste is smooth, round and malty. It also has touches of spices, fruits, caramel, sweet custard, apple pie, nuts, some bitterness of okkernut-peel and some hops.

Roasted cocoa and almonds with a bit of burnt character. Plums, raisins and caramel meld nicely. Feels initially dry with a bit of residual cnady sugar like sweetnees in the finish. very clean and round beer.
This is a good Abbey Dubbel.   Malty, sweet, and dark friut flavors.  Finishes clean, smooth, and crisp.
Unexpectedly hoppy aroma with a sweet and tart fruitiness that was even more pronounced in the finish.  Enjoyable and refreshing.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2005 Thanks to Bob, the bartender at the Hop Leaf, for buying us this one last beer of the night... and a 750 ml bottle at that!  Pouring light brown with a mediocre tan head, this has a refreshing yeasty fruitiness in the aroma along with the expected malt sweetness and a dash of hop bitterness.  This has a very soft and creamy mouthfeel and is smooth and easy to drink.  The flavor is caramel and toffee and vanilla with a mixture of fruit flavors - apple and dried fruits.  It finishes on a refreshing tart note.  Very good for a freebie!<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Leaf, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>
Amber with small head. Notes of sweetness  and yeast in the aroma. Notes of cinnamon in the beginning and yeast in the aftertaste.

Bouteille de 750 ml obtenue par importation privée via Bièropholie.  Arôme: Odeur dépices, de céréales et dagrumes. Apparence: Couleur ambrée foncée voilée. Petit col blanc mousseux. Aucune carbonisation.  Saveur: Goût dépices et de fumée. Durée de larrière goût moyen. Palette: Corps moyen avec une texture huileuse. Carbonisation moyenne. Léger arrière goût de fumée. (Rating #102)

Tasted in Los Angeles.  Obtained from PlumpJacks in Noe, San Francisco.  Although I am no beer expert, I did stay in a Holiday in select at the time of this writing. 

Appearance is copper / brown, slightly muddy.  Thin tan / tobacco coloured head - sustained. Aroma has an acidic / tangy scent with herbal notes.  Flavour is sweet with presence of caramel and vanilla and a bread or biscuit like yeasty mouthfeel.

2004 bottle from Downtown Liquors.  Deep caramel and stained oak browns swirl about in the glass with some lighter amber notes near the edges.  Perfect amount (not mountains, but not small clumps either) of foamy yellow-flecked, off-white head.  Cloudy and unfiltered.  Aroma of raisins, clean belgian yeast and moderately dry caramel.  Definitive notes of candi sugar.  Lightly herbal hops give some balance to the nose, but makes me think this less of a dubbel (not that I care).  To be honest, I hadnt looked at the style designation before drinking, and was expecting a darker saison (whatever that is).  It has the yeast notes, and some residual sugar of a dubbel, but seems more spicy and zesty.  Light apples futher confuse things, though I do seem to recall some light banana esters.  Lightly sugary finish with more raisins and yeast (lightly dry cheese as well).  Not a true abbey dubbel in my mind, just seems like a saison with dark candi sugar.  Moderate carbonation, no alcohol apparency.
(750 ml bottle)  Pours a lightly cloudy amber body with a large rocky beige head.  Aroma of spicy yeast (cheese, earth, mustiness, and leaves).  Flavor of raisins and spicy yeast.  Enjoyable!

Brownish orange, with not that much head that died off quickly.
Green apple aromas at first, followed by a freshly written off the blackboard chalky feeling, and then...dizzying and chemical like a felt pen marker.
Chocolate malty sweet, with some brown sugar, not much else.

interesting the moinette abbey dubbel (brown) and trippel (blonde) are both 8.5% abv and both texas labels have the same story and description. pretty great brune here. as great as the blonde and a dimension of brown (chocolate malt). soft, chocolate and herbal. great brune for chilly nights!

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2005 The Lure:Sweet and spicy cinnamon cream rise from the yeast, but are a bit too shy to really create interest. Head never dies though, and laces wonderfully.

The Festivities:Dusty candi sugar and green grass hoppiness unite in a comforting, harmless cake. Yeasty delicacies undermine its soul. I admit the "Brune" had me expecting some form of dark malt flavors (roastiness, sweetness, etc.), but there definitely werent any. This is well-rounded dubbel with perfect carbonation, and a most appeasing and diplomatic flavor profile. Even wiser around 2 years old.

Transcendence:Looking at the horizon, silent and content.

Green apples, brown sugar, fresh cut hay, some light spiciness.  Hazy burnished copper coloured body with shy ring of off-white head.  Brown sugar, grassy hops and a fair bitterness in the flavour.  Doesnt have the expected full-round maltiness.  Medium body is somewhat sticky with fairly strong carbonation.  Bottle (Bieropholie - Jun. 2004) sampled at the Voyager par des Papilles group tasting Feb-05.
Pours a hazy amber brown color with a very thin head. Sweet aroma and flavor of green apples and alcohol. Light to medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation.

750 mL bottle; cork date 2002: Poured a nice  mahogany, murky, with a compact dense tan head. Aroma of fruit and spice, almost like a dry white wine. Flavor had a somewhat sour edge, with lots of funky yeast and hops.  Mouthfeel was about perfect for the beer. It may have been somewhat past its prime, but it was still enjoyable, although at 3 years old I wouldnt have recognized it as a Dubbel.

750 ml bottle - Whip-In Liquors, Austin, Tx. Apricot and Peach colored pour, quite murky fith bits of sediment floating about. Has a frothy, medium thick khaki colored head.  Aroma has some alcohol, a bit of ginger and some yeast. Flavor is a bit complex - with chocolate, yeast, raisins, dates - blended together well. Mouthfeel is somewhat thick and creamy - a most enjoyable Dubbel.
Draught. Dark hazy red brown colour with a medium baige head. Sweet yeasty fruity cherry aroma and a sweet dry spicy malty taste. Medium body and a sweet finish.
Reddish brown colour with off white head. Sweet fruity aroma with hints of cherry. Malty flavor with some dark fruit and spices.

reddish brown app with medium, off-white head...aroma of cherries, lemons, and spices...flavor was a wonderful mixture of flowers, spices, sugars, cherries, caramels, and malts
impressive to say the least

Ruddy orange-red body with tons of yeast sediment; medium tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits (cherry, plum) and sweet breads, with a touch of cotton candy, honey, and plenty of esters, lending an interesting spicy character.  Surprisingly light and herbal flavor with flower petals, dark fruit, toast, apple, and residual sugars as well as spices (pepper, coriander), finishing dry and spicy.  A bit vinous.  Nicely complex; I didnt expect the herbal, spicy character to compete with the malts as it did.

750 mL bottle, corked & caged (2003 cork): mostly clear brown strawberry with thin off-white cream with amazing retention.  Yeasty aromatics with lightly buttered toast, dark malts and the faintest hints of hops and alcohol.  Tingly carbonation gives way to a creaminess that glides across the tongue.  Yeasty esters dominate a palate full of dark, luscious fruits (pears, red apples), biscuity malts, and chewy sourdough.  Finish is long, dry and peppery.  Enough depth and character to be considered a great brew, but simple enough to enjoy without much thought.

Bottled.
Red-brown, large beige head.
Ozon-ish aroma with pomegranate(?).
A bit sweet, a bit bitter, some alcoholic flavour.

Small tan head, fair retention, minimal lace, pop like head, fizzy. Yeasty, malty nose with citrus and dark fruit notes also. Lightly murky, brown/orange hued brew. Medium bodied, well carbonated start that settles down to make it an even more enjoyable drink. Nice maltyness, hints of caramel, mild sourness, medium kilned malts, brown? Hints of fruit, raisins, light bananna notes exposing themselves as it warms. Medium sweet finish showing some earthiness and alc. notes.

Red/brown, some couldiness, a big off-white head. Cidery nose with a touch of lemons, yeast, black pepper. Flavor is tangy, medium sweet, with a slightly harsh bitterness and some yeasty funk. Somewhat watery.

Cloudy umber color with a moderate luscious looking head of dark cream bubbles. Now this has an aroma! It fills the area after the pour and demands to be inhaled. Marmalade and toasted rye bread, with caramel, raisins, light herbs (rosemary) and dark candi. Heavy coating of bubbles line the glass with each quaff. Hard to imagine a brew looking any finer. Starts with dry retired barnyard cobwebs which slowly sweetness throughout. Perhaps a touch to sweet, but really, it should be expected in this style. Special B seems to be present for a nice malt touch. While a bit thick at time the effervescence seems to help carry away any stickiness. Alcohol come out a touch as it warms, but in no way a distraction. Interesting balance in his one, somewhat like watching a tennis match. Flavors swing from dry to sweet, hoppy and bitter to malty, thick to thin, just a lot of things going on. Not as warming as I might expect from the heft, but I do feel this one. Certainly one of the tops in this style in my book.

0.25 cl bottle. Nice redbrown color, small tan head. Sediments. Medium sweet toffee aroma with hint of yeast. Bittersweet flavor with long dry finish. This is one of the best brune i have had. Dupont knows how to make a good beer!

Medium brown in colour with slight orange hues. Thick, fluffy, and lasting cream coloured head. Strong corriander aroma with plenty of spicy hop aroma.  Nice malty sweetness that attempts to balance the abundant hoppy, spicy, peppery flavor. Medium bodied, dry finish.

Copper color with a slight haze and plentiful co2. Tawny head, rocky, with good retention and clingy lace.  Smells of malt, fruity esters, caramel, bubblegum and some tartness.  Flavor has a sweet start, peppery, with a yeasty dry/tart finish.  Mouthfeel is watery, medium bodied, and  lightly effervescent with a lingering biting finish. I tried to warm up o this beer, but the balance of tart/bitter to sweetness doesnt work for me.

Bottle pours reddish brown, quite cloudy with bits floating about, medium sized off-white foamy head, with somewhat decent lacing. &nbsp Sweet figgish like aroma. &nbsp Semi-sweet flavor, light dark pitted fruit. &nbsp Fairly full bodied, good mouthfeel. &nbsp Quick finish, but clean. &nbsp Decent.

Brown with a hze, lots of floating bits, beige head. A sweet candy scent, alcohol slightly noticeable. Malty sweet and nearly chewey. Vinous, sweet caramel, yeast and alcohol. Some tartness with oaky flavors in the middle with a sweet floral hop follow. Complicated yes, but it works.

On tap at Tellers in Cincinnati.  Light brown color, hazy.  Nose/flavor is very bananaish, yeasty and slightly breadish.  Well made.  Sweet finish.  Wish I could say more, but I was sitting at a bar and only making mental notes!
Brown/Amber Coloring with White Head.  Citrusy and Spicey..  Malty.. Dry on the Throat at the End..  Not a Bad Dubbel.
Golden brown w/small thick head. Sour lemon, yeasty nose, and grapefruit. Med weight w/drying finish. Raisen, cocoa, fig, malt, roasted nuts and wood all sho on the palate. Nice beer!

Subtle; faint sweetness in back of the tongue. Beautiful color; red, yellow, orange. Off-white head. Hazy to murky body. Not much lace. Color makes up for that. Rich, highly carbonated mouthfeel. Caramel notes. Simply wonderful.
Hazy brown color with a thin head.  Sweet malt aroma.  Malty taste with a hint of banana and a slightly buttery palate.  Not too shabby.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2004 750mL. Superb looks. So murky it seems to have a few range of colors in the copper to orange department. Eternal lasting 1cm head from an initially huge cream head. Aroma is extremely yeasty, creamy. Banana cookies and mild caramel combined on a sheet of lactose. Musty and cellary flavors are underwhelmed under a milky or buttery character. It smells rather fluffy. Palate displays dominating yeasty as expected. Finish is short and yeasty with a big slightly tart clove character. Very bready, almost salty aftertaste. Full bodied, very high carbonation. It could have been a weizenbock... Given that this is from Dupont, its a disappointment to me and seems quite controversial for a lot of people looking at the ratings.
Bottle picked up in Belgium. Chocolately, malty dubbel type beer. The blonde is better, but this is still really good. Well done Dupont!

Quite an old bottle, aged in my closet for three years, but labeled as just plain Moinette Brune (no mention of the "II").
Hoppy nose, dry and grassy. Soft fruits at the front, apple, nuts, sugary.  Some sourness at the finish.
This reminded me of a blueberry muffin with those large sugar crystals sprinkled all over the top.  Some orange peels thrown in for add taste.

GHBF: Thanks for the aged bottle Joe. Murky brown hue with a small frothy tan head and some lace. The aroma has notes of hazelnut, toasted and caramelized mats, aromatic and bitters, and a earthy yeast ester. The taste starts somewhat candi sweet but a nice dose of fruity acidic character and spice clean up the palate. Some sourness creeps through with a nutty finish. The feel is good, nothing special. A very good brew and worthy of a try. Seemed to have aged well.
A tan head over a cloudy brown beer. Aromas of malt, spice, yeast, and earth.  Flavor is malty, spicy, earthy, with a surprisingly light body.  Dry mouthfeel, with the alcohol pretty well hidden.

2003 on cork.  Pours with a voluminous head that looks like a cafe latte.  The head lasted for the entire glass.   Yeasty, spicy, earthy aroma.  Fairly sour up front, resolving into a bitter maltiness with a little dark fruit.  Very hoppy finish.  I like it.

Pours a murky dark copper brown with a thick, puffy off-white head.  Aroma of soft caramel malts, bready Belgian yeast, and a touch of farmhouse florals.  Starts sweet and malty with a touch of tartness toward a bready dry finish.  Nice saison character goes doen smooth and has a decent balance.  Thanks to hopsrus for this nice brew.

Bottle. Rusty brown with no head. Vinegar like nose. tastes like apple juice, malt vinegar, and an Abbey Dubbel mixed. Kinda sour in a good way. Some caramel and cdried cherries on the back end. Its okay, but it falls short.

pours a hazy brown with a white head that is gone before i can taste it. aroma of yeast earth and sweetness. watered down mouth feel, taste is bitter almost vinegar fruit flavor. very astringent and acidic that does not sit well.

Cork dated 2002. Sampled Aug. 2004. Pours a murky amber-orange color. Fluffy durable head. Nose reminiscent of yeast rolls, herbs, banana, spices and dark fruit. First sip reveals a definite tart sourness, almost lactic. This is quickly followed by a emerging sweetness of malt, figs, caramel and cherries. Mid-palate seems to reveal some watery thiness, although the hops surely make their statement in the snappy, pleasantly bitter finish. Not a lot of complexity, but has some class.

Yeasty, spicy and thinner than I anticipated. Fruity but fermented - cherries, I think. Thin. Malty, with a very spicy on the tip of the tongue yeast big time. Good, but not as I thought it would be...
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: 750 ml bottle, 2003.  Murky medium copper/brown with a full, lasting off-white head.  Strong orangy whiff immediately, caramel-banana and a hint of cherries as it warms.  On the tongue, spicy, darkly fruity (figs and bing cherries), wet and juicy at first but fairly dry and spicy to finish.
Reminds me of some of the Flemish Ales in its subtle sourness.  A nice tart ale with slight malty tones.  Balanced with a slight hoppy bitterness.  Not bad.

This was a pleasant surprise - the brown label sure wasnt enticing.  Poured a hazy brown with an everlasting tan head and good lacing.  Smooth bodied and well carbonated, the flavors and aromas were earthy, yeasty, caramel, lime-lemon edges, plum and spices and sweet dark fruits.  It kept getting better and better.

Cork date 2003, Sampled August 2004
Pours a hazy amber to light brown color, and is crowned by a prodigious light brown head.  As the beer warms up it becomes brilliantly clear and a rich amber color.  Aromas of plums, raisins, brown sugar, and a bit of herbal spiciness are all found in the nose.  Lightly sweet taste up front leads to a sharp herbal note in the finish that is characteristic of the Dupont beers.  There is a solid malty sweet component here that reminds me of brown sugar.  The sharp, spicy yeast notes meld quite well with the rich malty caramel notes.  This beer is fairly light on the palate, though not as light as a typical pale Saison.  Also because of the malt character this is much more fruity than the pale versions, there are notes of raisin, plum, and a hint of rich fig character.  This is quite tasty.  It really softens up as it warms, the brown sugar & fruit notes really start to come to the fore.

Orange beer.
Acidic aroma with tones of choclate, rocks, malt and fruits.
Fruity flavour with tones of chocolate. Dry finish.

2003: Hazy orange-brown...definate yeast and caramel aroma...medium light brown head...not quite what I was expecting to hit my tongue...definate malt, caramel, dark fruits...then oh man what a finish...that is DEFINATELY not what I was expecting...incredibly bitter and all at once too...very crisp and dry at the end...maybe an older bottle would finish more smoothly...

Malty sweet, rubbery aroma. Loe hops. Dark amber-brown hazy, with off-white lacing head. Medium body with medium-high carbonation. Starts sweet and malty. Raisins, port. Nice hop bitter finish, Begian ale flavor. Light alcohol, dry. After is sweet, malty, chalky.

2002... Poured a hazy reddish orange color with a small light tan head and some light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of yeast, sweet dark fruits, tart cherries, light hops, and also a lightly funky barnyard aspect.  Predominantly vinous taste of caramel malt which was lightly spiced, some tart cherry, and yeast as well.  Nicely carbonated, though thinner than I would have expected.  Thanks hopsrus!

Aroma is of yeast, malt (caramel), fruit (grapes, citrus) and a bit soapy. Very good appearnce: Hazy, brown coloured with an off-white-brown, creamy and lasting head. Particles floating around. Taste is of malts (caramel, roasted), fruit  (grapes, citrus), yeast and some hopbitterness. Sticky mouthfeel. More dry palate in the finish. Alcohol reasonable hidden. Decent, enjoyable brew. When I have this beer another time and it is still decent and enjoyable, perhaps I should rate this one higher.

Off-white, mostly diminishing head.  Hazy, brown-amber body.  Hoppy and malty aroma, alcohol too.  Heavily bitter iniital flavour, heavily bitter (long-lasting) finish.  Medium to full body.  Watery texture.  Lively carbonation. Very nice beer.
Redbrown, nice head. Yeast falling to the bottom of the glass. Aroma from grapefruit, citrus and sweet perfume. Aroma is almond and yeasty. Some bitterness in the finish
Hazy amber, nice lasting offwhite head. Aroma is yeasty and from citrru. But there are also sweeter touches, maybe from banana. Flavor is fruity at first but then it turns bitter and hoppy.

Bottle 2003 vintage. Apple, bubble gum and some spicy herbal notes in the nose. Nice cloudy red/brown color  with a rocky off white head and  good lacing. Light bitterness with a slight acidic flavor. Kind of yeasty too. Some yeast may have gotten in  suspension so I guess I well have to try it again some other time.

I can see how this would be good with slightly spicy or extremely flavorful foods like marinated meats and barbecue. The acidity from the berry/vinous notes would accent both well. Didnt note a lot of herbs. Hay (no pungency) and citrus aroma. Ive never heard the word "sturdy" in reference to a beer but it is that. Im not sure Id have it again; I do enjoy the dark rich berry aspect though.

2002 vintage: Particle-laden rufous. Hallmark Dupont foam with plenty of sticky  creaminess. Clean aroma underlain with cedar, musty yeast, coconut oil, white grapes, bubblegum, and tight fruity esters. Malty, as well, with a light airiness amplifying the pepper and plum qualities. Expanisve, yet creamy, carbonation. Light spritz. Starts peppery and well-carbonated teamed with mineral and peach skins. Trace of plump fruit acidity and vague yeast astringency in the center are softened by delicate esters and muted flower tones. Finishes on the dry side with plump peach notes and a chalky yeast backbone amid a blend of coarse hop bitterness, white grapes, and melon. Peach and lightly sweet malt remnants. Yeast addition imparts more dryness while accentuating the pepper. Much like a Dubbel crossed with the mustiness/tartness of an Oud Bruin. Elegantly understated brew.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: 750ml Bottle 2002 Vintage: Beautiful orange colored beer has the expected massive head this one being off white and nicely retained.  Aroma is delicious in my book, being heavily yeasty, with some sweet maltiness, alcohol, and wet wood.  Flavor is mouth filling with lots going on.  Sweet fruit flavor like raisins, very nice spiciness and a bone dry finish.  This is very repeatable and quite underrated IMO.

(sampled draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden) Hazy amber appearence with a wonderful creamy tan head. Rich aroma of yeast, nectarine and spices. Fruity flavour of banana, pears, lemon and yeast in a firm malty body. Small notes of acidity. Long fruity finish.

2002.  Rusting copper with a thick, fluffy eggshell-colored head.  The aroma is sweet and quite malty with emphasis on the caramel, fresh dough, oranges, apples, cherries, plum, toasted bread, chocolate, fresh hops and light, spicy alcohol.  The palate is soft but lacks some of the texture necessary to be world-class.  The flavors are nice, but perhaps a touch too sweet.  The fruit dominates but is backed up by the lightly toasted malts, spicy alcohol and bitter, hop finish.  Honestly, I expected a little more from DuPont, as they are one of my favorite breweries.  Actually, I hope more for a Loterbol Bruin.  Either way, I could have done far worse.

Dark, hazy amber; small but persistent crème head. Flowery, honey, lunaria in the nose. Sweet - and sweat (as in human-) in the taste. Fully sweet palate with a marked spicey finish. Well bodied, oily texture. I'll just never like it as much as the blonde. But it's well worth trying.

Pours with a huge off white head and a cloudy deep amber body. Very carbonated. Aroma of dried fruits,... figs raisins, ripe pear, and alcohol. Slightly spicy hoppiness in the first sip leading to a rush of sourness thanks to open fermentation and some pretty amazing little bacteria. Really over the top sourness. Too much for me but this could be someone elses cup of tea. The beer is still young and I bet will develop some intense flavors as it ages. I would also bet that some of the sourness will mellow out.

I must say that I have discovered Dupont Brasserie to be a very fine brewery indeed. This one pours a frothy head on a light amber body. Aroma is very fruity and malty. I also sense some spices, pepper and a nice mild alcohol scent. Flavor bites at first with lots of spices and dark malt but turns to a nice mild fruity tone with a dry finish. A little mild but a very nice beer!

Cloudy golden color,tall creamy head that lasted for some time and left a very nice lace behind.The aroma was malty and fruity with a nice spice and mild hop presence.Malty sweet taste with a nice spice coming through mild alcohol and mild hops with a nice mild spicey finish.I wasn't expecting much from this little brew but it does quite nicely and is well worth trying a few more.
Dark amber color, no head. Fruity, a bot sour aroma. Slightly alcoholic, sweetish, full-bodied flavor. A throughly enjoyable, easily drinkable dubbel.

Amber body, swirling central jet of carbonation (in my Chimay glass), and a massive Belgian-style cream head. Smells of toasted candy sugar, apples, warm caramel, and yeasty bread. Very malty with tangy fruit qualities. Initially sweetness dominates but then the bitterness comes along slowly. Nice full body. Pleasing.

Pours a reddish brown with a foamy tan head. Aroma is comprised of spice, candy sugar, and malt mixed with a slight floral bouquet. Tastes similar to most other dubbels with some spice, sweetened malt, flowers, slight earthiness and fruit. I could swear I taste a taste similar to a watered down Westy 12. Or at least similar tastes. The 8.5% is not noticeable to me. Good beer!

[Warning: I have only tasted it once, from a bottle was nearing its "best before" date. For what I know, a fresh bottle may taste different.] Dark amber. One finger tall beige head, lasting forever. Strong sugary aroma; caramel, cherries and brandy. Tastes rich and syrupy, even a bit cloying if you ask me. Full bodied and thick. Some bitterness in the finish, even if the hops don't shine. Still a good brew.

Not a pronounced nose by any means, but pleasant. Dark gold/brown color and a lathery head. Yeasty taste initially singaling its Belgian origin immediately. Spicy, peppery and a little cloves. Raisins and licorice come clearly through as well. Pretty nice strong ale.
super spritzy aroma with a hint of orange, cloudy yellow with a big but quickly dissipating head, dry and clovey, slight creaminess, a solid bitter finish, a great  beer but nothing too memorable
White Horse, London: Apricot, apple bubble gum like nose. Nicer amber light color, Short sharp dry bitter finish. Nice.
Absolutely amazing fruity, herbal, hoppy and mature aroma. The same elements appear in the flavour, but not as overwhelming as in the aroma. Another Belgian masterpiece.
KegHazy red-amber color. Some malt and alcohol nose, light wood. Round taste, malty, light astringency, not impressive, less than the Blonde. Ordinary palate.
A dissapinting beer. Dark amber, thick creamy rocky head. Nice sweet estery aroma. A little thin on flavour and dry. Generally dray and alcoholic: not a nice combination.  Some background esters.

Incredible beer. Very powerful and full-bodied. Chestnut flavour and rather sweet and malty. This beer is so full-bodied and so complex it is amazing! Aroma really hits you hard in the face and so does the flavour.
Small, light brown, creamy head. Red-brown colour. Nose is alcohol and fruit(overripe apples, perhaps banana?). Medium to full body. Taste is sweet, caramel followed by bitterness. Good.

(750ml, bottled 2/02):  Cloudy orange-brown body with healthy beige head.  Aroma is strong -- fruity (mango) and sweet, slightly floral as well.  Caramel and toffee appear as it warms, as does light alcohol.  Taste is sweet, fruity and floral/herbal hoppy, with some caramel around the edges.  Finish is floral and sweet, with hint of alcohol.  Dregs add some nice yeast/spice to the equation.  Medium-full body.  Wait about 30 minutes out of the fridge before trying -- needs to be at least 55 degrees, probably 60.

Shockingly, it's a brown color . . . with some ruddy amber higlights.  Cloudy, but not opaque.  Aroma is sweet and mild, a bit like mango with a little brown sugar.  Flavor is mildly sweet and gentle.  There's a tiny bit of brown sugar in it with a hint of granny smith apple and a slightly yeasty finish.  Pleasant.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2003 The aroma is powerful; sweet and yeasty. The color is an unclear dark orange, and it has a small disappearing head. The flavor is sweet with notes of earth and yeast and ending on a dryness.
heather, bit of tropical fruit - kiwi, papaya - nice yeast and hints of soft crumb sourdough, sour finish is eqasy and long. a bit of toast. what a joy!
Hoppy, citric, perfumy aroma. Hopbitter, slightly citric flavor, with coffee and some caramel. Prickly with a long bitter finish.
Red-brown, average head. Malty, fruity, some sourness and pretty sweet, but not as full-flavoured as i was hoping for. Short and bitter finish.
Bottled Reddish brown with average head and a wealth of sediment. Heavy buttery estery aroma of banana and toffee. Sweet and rather malty. Pleasant bitterish rather hoppy finish.
UPDATED: JUN 13, 2003 Copper coloured beer with a big kight brown-red creamy head. Slightly fruity-sour, aged malty aroma and taste. Slightly sweet start with a light bitter sharp alcohol finish.

Cloudy, deep purple in color.  Lots of sweet malts in the nose, but a very heavy fruitiness came out in the taste....grape taffy.  The mouthfeel was very thick, almost syruppy...went back with a slight acidity.  Lots of sediment remained as I finished this beer.
UPDATED: JAN 19, 2003 On the light side for a Brune.  Thin mouthfeel and somewhat weak flavor.  Decent but not the best brune I have had.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2006 750ml 2006 bottle. Head is initially large, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium amber, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (caramel, toasted grain, cookie), lightly to moderately yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of brown sugar, raisin, clove, orange peel. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic. What can I say?  Great aroma, appearance, and very nicely balanced.
Cloudy amber brown color, lasting head. Spicy aroma, also bit citrus fruity. Malty taste of caramel indeed, sweet and a bit sour even. Lasting palate.
Cloudy amber coloured. Decent head. In the aroma theres spices. Coriander, citrus and the like. Flavour is somewhat sweet and has notes of caramel. Notes of alcahol in the end as well.
golden syrup and smoked eel. really tasty
nougat. nougat nougat nougat nougat nougat. nougat? nougat. nice yeasty grassy smell + lemon + roof of mouth stickiness + plenty of aforementioned.
Not very appealing brown color; Head thickened and then faded- not much lace; Almond nose. Dry alcohol notes to start. Not much fruit accents. Unremarkable and non-offensive. Laughty-fin-dah.
OK, kind of yeasty nose, quite sweet at the start, and then heads to a yeasty, acidic finish, not really my kind of beer, but not too bad.
An odd sourness persists, combined with other nasty flavors.  Tastes a bit like a shot of Jaegermeister crossed with Ouzo.  Ouch!  Discard and drink the Vervifontaine instead.
A murky brew, this.  Good winter fruits for starters followed by dubbel characteristics.  Dangerously strong.

Pours a very cloudy brown, big olde fuzzy deep beige head and tons of lace. Caramel sweet nose, malts, fruity, start is slightly sweet, the middle thin, and the finish is sour, acidic, with hints of chocolate tones, alcohol is present as is the hops, not bad, but a bit thin.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2004 Cherry, prune and nutty aroma. Hazy, reddish brown, beige head, good lace. Sweet, bitter, fruity, nutty, prune, sour in the back, sticky. Quite a complex beer which at first it great but after half a bottle a starts getting annoying.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2004 1999 vintage, sampled 03/2004 -hazy amber-brown colour, big creamy head, chocolate and buttery aroma, malty with some vinous notes, creamy and full-bodied, sweet and bitter with a biscuity maltiness, long dry malty finish - as always with this brewery: a very good beer.
